direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 Total darkness. We hear an old man's voice, distinct and in distress. It is OLD SALIERI. He uses a mixture of English and occasionally Italian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A faint light illuminates the screen. Flickeringly, we see an eighteenth century balustrade and a flight of stone stairs. We are looking down into the wall of the staircase from the point of view of the landing. Up the stair is coming a branched candlestick held by Salieri's VALET. By his side is Salieri's COOK, bearing a large dish of sugared cakes and biscuits. Both men are desperately worried: the Valet is thin and middle-aged; the Cook, plump and Italian. It is very cold. They wear shawls over their night-dresses and clogs on their feet. They wheeze as they climb. The candles throw their shadows up onto the peeling walls of the house, which is evidently an old one and in bad decay. A cat scuttles swiftly between their bare legs, as they reach the salon door. The Valet tries the handle. It is locked. Behind it the voice goes on, rising in volume.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Valet knocks gently on the door. The voice stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The voice of Old Salieri continues again, further off now, and louder. We hear a noise as if a window is being opened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two servants look at each other in alarm. Then the Valet hands the candlestick to the Cook and takes a sugared cake from the dish, scrambling as quickly as he can back down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart! Mozart! Mozart. Forgive me! Forgive your assassin! Mozart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show some mercy! I beg you. I beg you! Show mercy to a guilty man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open the door, Signore! Please! Be good now! We've brought you something special. Something you're going to love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Signore Salieri! Open the door. Come now. Be good!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart! Mozart! I confess it! Listen! I confess!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The street is filled with people: ten cabs with drivers, five children, fifteen adults, two doormen, fifteen dancing couples and a sled and three dogs. It is a windy night. Snow is falling and whirling about. People are passing on foot, holding their cloaks tightly around them. Some of them are revelers in fancy dress: they wear masks on their faces or hanging around their necks, as if returning from parties. Now they are glancing up at the facade of the old house. The window above the street is open and Old Salieri stands there calling to the sky: a sharp-featured, white-haired Italian over seventy years old, wearing a stained dressing gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door of the house bursts open. The Valet hobbles out, holding the sugared cake. The wind catches at his shawl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old Salieri stares down at him. Some of the passersby have now stopped and are watching this spectacle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old Salieri looks at him in contempt. Then he turns away back into the room, shutting the window with a bang. Through the glass, the old man stares down at the group of onlookers in the street. They stare back at him in confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He makes a sign indicating 'crazy,' and goes back inside the house. The onlookers keep staring.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart! Mozart! I cannot bear it any longer! I confess! I confess what I did! I'm guilty! I killed you! Sir I confess! I killed you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart, perdonami! Forgive your assassin! Piet! Piet! Forgive your assassin! Forgive me! Forgive! Forgive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up to the window) That's all right, Signore! He heard you! He forgave you! He wants you to go inside now and shut the window!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Signore! Look what I have for you! I can't give it to you from down here, can I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one, sir. He'll be all right. Poor man. He's a little unhappy, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Cook is standing holding the candlestick in one hand, the dish of cakes in the other. The Valet arrives, panting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Cook, scared, shakes his head: no. The Valet again knocks on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He eats the sugared cake in his hand, elaborately and noisily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear a thump from inside the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear a terrible, throaty groaning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks down. From under the door we see a trickle of blood flowing. In horror, the two men stare at it. The dish of cakes falls from the Cook's hand and shatters. He sets the candlestick down on the floor. Both servants run at the door frantically - once, twice, three times - and the frail lock gives. The door flies open. Immediately, the stormy, frenzied opening of Mozart's Symphony No. 25 (the Little G Minor) begins. We see what the servants see.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did he open?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here I am, Signore. Now open the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmmm - this is good! This is the most delicious thing I ever ate, believe me! Signore, you don't know what you're missing! Mmmm!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now that's enough, Signore! Open!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you don't open this door, we're going to eat everything. There'll be nothing left for you. And I'm not going to bring you anything more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Old Salieri lies on the floor in a pool of blood, an open razor in his hand. He has cut his throat but is still alive. He gestures at them. They run to him. Barely, we glimpse the room - an old chair, old tables piled with books, a forte- piano, a chamber-pot on the floor - as the Valet and the Cook struggle to lift their old Master, and bind his bleeding throat with a napkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty-five dancing couples, fifty guests, ten servants, full orchestra. As the music slows a little, we see a Masquerade Ball in progress. A crowded room of dancers is executing the slow portion of a dance fashionable in the early 1820's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the fast music returns, we see Old Salieri being carried out of his house on a stretcher by two attendants, and placed in a horse-drawn wagon under the supervision of a middle- aged doctor in a tall hat. This is DOCTOR GULDEN. He gets in beside his patient. The driver whips up the horse, and the wagon dashes off through the still-falling snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE WAGON - NIGHT The wagon is galloping through the snowy streets of the city. Inside the conveyance we see Old Salieri wrapped in blankets, half-conscious, being held by the hospital attendants. Doctor Gulden stares at him grimly. The wagon arrives outside the General Hospital of Vienna.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: FOUR STREETS OF VIENNA AND INT

direction.raw_text: A wide, white-washed corridor. Doctor Gulden is walking down it with a priest, a man of about forty, concerned, but somewhat self-important. This is Father VOGLER, Chaplain at the hospital. In the corridor as they walk, we note several patients -- some of them visibly disturbed mentally. All patients wear white linen smocks. Doctor Gulden wears a dark frock-coat; Vogler, a cassock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop outside a door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vogler nods and opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's going to live. It's much harder to cut your throat than most people imagine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here we are. Do you wish me to come in with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Doctor. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A bare room - one of the best available in the General Hospital. It contains a bed, a table with candles, chairs, a small forte-piano of the early nineteenth century. As Vogler enters, Old Salieri is sitting in a wheel-chair, looking out the window. His back is to us. The priest closes the door quietly behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old Salieri turns around to look at him. We see that his throat is bandaged expertly. He wears hospital garb, and over it the Civilian Medal and Chain with which we will later see the EMPEROR invest him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He propels his wheelchair to the forte-piano, and plays an unrecognizable melody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays another tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays it with growing enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Salieri?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Father Vogler. I am a Chaplain here. I thought you might like to talk to someone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tried to take your life. You do remember that, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the sight of God that is a sin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you understand that you have sinned? Gravely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cannot leave alone a soul in pain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who I am? You never heard of me, did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That makes no difference. All men are equal in God's eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Offer me your confession. I can offer you God's forgiveness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not seek forgiveness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My son, there is something dreadful on your soul. Unburden it to me. I'm here only for you. Please talk to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How well are you trained in music?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know a little. I studied it in my youth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here in Vienna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you must know this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't say I do. What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm surprised you don't know. It was a very popular tune in its day. I wrote it. How about this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This one brought down the house when we played it first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S We see the pretty soprano KATHERINA CAVALIERI, now about twenty-four, dressed in an elaborate mythological Persian costume, singing on stage. She's near the end of a very florid aria by Salieri. The audience applauds wildly.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: THE STAGE OF AN OPERA HOUSE

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - 1823 OLD SALIERI (taking his hands off the keys) Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slyly he plays the opening measure of Mozart's Eine Kleine Nachtmusik. The priest nods, smiling suddenly, and hums a little with the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very long pause. Salieri stares above the priest, seemingly lost in his own private world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A further pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Old Salieri turns to him, a look of extreme innocence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I regret it is not too familiar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you recall no melody of mine? I was the most famous composer in Europe when you were still a boy. I wrote forty operas alone. What about this little thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I know that! That's charming!  I didn't know you wrote that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't. That was Mozart. Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. You know who that is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. The man you accuse yourself of killing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah - you've heard that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All Vienna has heard that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ( eagerly) And do they believe it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you believe it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For God's sake, my son, if you have anything to confess, do it now! Give yourself some peace!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you hear me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was murdered, Father! Mozart! Cruelly murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost whispering) Yes? Did you do it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was my idol! I can't remember a time when I didn't know his name! When I was only fourteen he was already famous. Even in Legnago - the tiniest town in Italy - I knew of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S There are twelve children and twenty adults in the square. We see the fourteen-year-old Salieri blindfolded, playing a game of Blindman's Bluff with other Italian children, running about in the bright sunshine and laughing.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: A SMALL TOWN SQUARE IN LOMBARDY, ITALY

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I was still playing childish games when he was playing music for kings and emperors. Even the Pope in Rome!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S We see the six-year-old MOZART, also blindfolded, seated in a gilded chair on a pile of books, playing the harpsichord for the POPE and a suite of CARDINALS and other churchmen. Beside the little boy stands LEOPOLD, his father, smirking with pride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The piece finishes. Leopold lowers the lid of the harpsichord and lifts up his little son to stand on it. Mozart removes the blindfold to show a pale little face with staring eyes. Both father and son bow. A Papal Chamberlain presents Leopold with a gold snuff box whilst the cardinals decorously applaud. Over this scene Old Salieri speaks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I admit I was jealous when I heard the tales they told about him. Not of the brilliant little prodigy himself, but of his father, who had taught him everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My father did not care for music. He wanted me only to be a merchant, like himself. As anonymous as he was. When I told how I wished I could be like Mozart, he would say, Why? Do you want to be a trained monkey? Would you like me to drag you around Europe doing tricks like a circus freak? How could I tell him what music meant to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Serene music of the Italian Baroque - Pergolesi's Stabat Mater - sung by a choir of boys with organ accompaniment. We see the outside of the 17th-century church sitting in the wide landscape of Lombardy: sunlit fields, a dusty, white road, poplar trees.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: A COUNTRY CHURCH IN NORTH ITALY

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The music continues and swells. We see the twelve-year-old Salieri seated between his plump and placid parents in the congregation, listening in rapture. His father is a heavy- looking, self-approving man, obviously indifferent to the music. A large and austere Christ on the cross hangs over the altar. Candles burn below his image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy falls forward on his knees. So do his parents and the other members of the congregation. He stares up at Christ who stares back at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music swells to a crescendo. The candles flare. We see the Christ through the flames looking at the boy benignly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Even then a spray of sounded notes could make me dizzy, almost to falling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Whilst my father prayed earnestly to God to protect commerce, I would offer up secretly the proudest prayer a boy could think of. Lord, make me a great composer! Let me celebrate your glory through music - and be celebrated myself! Make me famous through the world, dear God! Make me immortal! After I die let people speak my name forever with love for what I wrote! In return I vow I will give you my chastity - my industry, my deepest humility, every hour of my life. And I will help my fellow man all I can. Amen and amen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And do you know what happened? A miracle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S CU, a large cooked fish on a thick china plate. Camera pulls back to show the Salieri family at dinner. Father Salieri sits at the head of the table, a napkin tucked into his chin. Mother Salieri is serving the fish into portions and handing them round. Two maiden aunts are in attendance, wearing black, and of course the young boy. Father Salieri receives his plate of fish and starts to eat greedily. Suddenly there is a gasp - he starts to choke violently on a fish bone. All the women get up and crowd around him, thumping and pummeling him, but it is in vain. Father Salieri collapses.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: DINING ROOM IN THE SALIERI HOUSE

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - 1823 OLD SALIERI Suddenly he was dead. Just like that! And my life changed forever. My mother said, Go. Study music if you really want to. Off with you! And off I went as quick as I could and never saw Italy again. Of course, I knew God had arranged it all; that was obvious. One moment I was a frustrated boy in an obscure little town. The next I was here, in Vienna, city of musicians, sixteen years old and studying under Gluck! Gluck, Father. Do you know who he was? The greatest composer of his time. And he loved me! That was the wonder. He taught me everything he knew. And when I was ready, introduced me personally to the Emperor! Emperor Joseph - the musical king!  Within a few years I was his court composer. Wasn't that incredible? Imperial Composer to His Majesty! Actually the man had no ear at all, but what did it matter? He adored my music, that was enough. Night after night I sat right next to the Emperor of Austria, playing duets with him, correcting the royal sight-reading. Tell me, if you had been me, wouldn't you have thought God had accepted your vow? And believe me, I honoured it. I was a model of virtue. I kept my hands off women, worked hours every day teaching students, many of them for free, sitting on endless committees to help poor musicians - work and work and work, that was all my life. And it was wonderful! Everybody liked me. I liked myself. I was the most successful musician in Vienna. And the happiest. Till he came. Mozart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A grand room crowded with guests. A small group of Gypsy musicians is playing in the background. Thirteen members of the Archbishop's orchestra - all wind players, complete with 18th-century wind instruments: elaborate-looking bassoons, basset horns, etc. and wearing their employer's livery - are laying out music on stands at one end of the room. At the other end is a large gilded chair, bearing the arms of the ARCHBISHOP OF SALZBURG. A throng of people is standing, talking, and preparing to sit upon the rows of waiting chairs to hear a concert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Salieri, age thirty-one, a neat, carefully turned-cut man in decent black clothes and clean white linen, walking through the crowd of guests. We follow him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see shots of assorted young men staring back at Salieri as he moves through the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the men recognize Salieri and bow respectfully. Then suddenly a servant bearing a large tray of cakes and pastries stalks past. Instantly riveted by the sight of such delights, Salieri follows him out of the Grand Salon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) One day he came to Vienna to play some of his music at the residence of his employer, the Prince-Archbishop of Salzburg. Eagerly I went there to seek him out. That night changed my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) As I went through the salon, I played a game with myself. This man had written his first concerto at the age of four; his first symphony at seven; a full-scale opera at twelve. Did it show? Is talent like that written on the face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Which one of them could he be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The servant marches along bearing his tray of pastries aloft. Salieri follows him. The servant turns into:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Salieri's POV: several tables, dressed to the floor with cloths are loaded with many plates of confectionery. It is, in fact, Salieri's idea of paradise! The servant puts his tray down on one of the tables and withdraws from the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Salieri turns away so as not to be noticed by the servant. As soon as the man disappears, Salieri sneaks into the buffet room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Salieri enters the room and looks about him cautiously. He is salivating with anticipation as he stares at the feast of sweet things. His attention is attracted in particular by a huge pile of dark chocolate balls arranged in the shape of a pineapple. He reaches out a hand to steal one of the balls, but at the same moment he hears giggling coming toward him. He ducks down behind the pastry table. A girl - CONSTANZE - rushes into the room. She runs straight across it and hides herself behind one of the tables. After a beat of total silence, MOZART runs into the room, stops, and looks around. He is age twenty-six, wearing a fine wig and a brilliant coat with the insignia of the Archbishop of Salzburg upon it. He is puzzled; Constanze has disappeared. Baffled, he turns and is about to leave the room, when Constanze suddenly squeaks from under the cloth like a tiny mouse. Instantly Mozart drops to all fours and starts crawling across the floor, meowing and hissing like a naughty cat. Watched by an astonished Salieri, Mozart disappears under the cloth and obviously pounces upon Constanze. We hear a high-pitched giggle, which is going to characterize Mozart throughout the film.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The throng is mostly seated. The musicians are in their places, holding their various exotic-looking wind instruments; the candles are all lit. A Majordomo appears and bangs his staff on the floor for attention. Immediately COLLOREDO, Prince-Archbishop of Salzburg enters. He is a small self- important figure of fifty in a wig, surmounted by a scarlet skullcap. He is followed by his Chamberlain, the Count ARCO. Everyone stands. The Archbishop goes to his throne and sits. His guests sit also. Arco gives the signal to start the music. Nothing happens. Instead, a wind musician gets up, approaches the Chamberlain and whispers in his ear. Arco in turn whispers to the Archbishop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart is not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're looking for him, Your Grace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Three servants are opening doors and looking into rooms going off the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The guests are turning around and looking at the Archbishop. The musicians are watching. There is puzzlement and a murmur of comment. The Archbishop tightens his lip.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Arco) We'll start without him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart is on his knees before the tablecloth, which reaches to the floor. Under it is Constanze. We hear her giggling as he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs her ankle. She screams. He pulls her out by her leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They roll on the floor. He tickles her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to drag her back under the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs delightedly, then addresses an imaginary Archbishop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives a high pitched giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mood becomes suddenly softer. She kisses him. They embrace. Then he spoils it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shocked, she strikes at him. At the same moment the music starts in the salon next door. We hear the opening of the Serenade for Thirteen Wind Instruments, K.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaps up, disheveled and rumpled and runs out of the room. Salieri watches in amazement and disgust.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miaouw! Miaouw! Mouse-wouse? It's Puss-wuss, fangs-wangs. Paws-claws. Pounce-bounce!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it. Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am! I am! I'm stopping it - slowly. You see! Look, I've stopped. Now we are going back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! No! No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! Back! Back! Listen - don't you know where you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are in the Residence of the Fartsbishop of Salzburg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fartsbishop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Grace, I've got something to tell you. I want to complain about this man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, tell him. Tell them all. They won't understand you anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because here everything goes backwards. People walk backwards, dance backwards, sing backwards, and talk backwards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? People fart backwards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think that's funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I think it's brilliant. You've been doing it for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, ha, ha, ha.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sra-I'm-sick! Sra-I'm sick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you are. You're very sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no. Say it backwards, shit-wit. Sra-I'm-sick Say it backwards!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (working it out) Sra-I'm-sick. Sick - kiss I'm - my Kiss my! Sra-I'm-sick - Kiss my arse!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Em iram! Em iram!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not playing this game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, this is serious. Say it backwards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just say it - you'll see. It's very serious. Em iram!  Em iram!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Iram - marry Em - marry me! No, no! You're a fiend. I'm not going to marry a fiend. A dirty fiend at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ui-vol-i-tub!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tub - but i-tub - but I vol - love but I love ui - You. I love you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tish-I'm tee. What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tish-I'm-tee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eat my - ah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My music! They've started! They've started without me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The music is louder. Mozart hastens towards the Grand Salon away from the buffet room, adjusting his dress as he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The opening of the Serenade is being tentatively conducted by the leader of the wind-musicians. Guests turn around as Mozart appears - bowing to the Archbishop - and walks with an attempt at dignity to the dais where the wind band is playing. The leader yields his place to the composer and Mozart smoothly takes over conducting. Constanze, deeply embarrassed, sneaks into the room and seats herself at the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The music fades down. Salieri stands shocked from his inadvertent eavesdropping. After a second he moves almost in a trance toward the door; the music dissolves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart is conducting the Adagio from his Serenade (K. 361), guiding the thirteen wind instrumentalists. The squeezebox opening of the movement begins. Salieri appears at the door at the back of the salon. He stares in disbelief at Mozart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music swells up and Salieri listens to it with eyes closed - amazed, transported - suddenly engulfed by the sound. Finally it fades down and away and changes into applause. Salieri opens his eyes. The audience is clearly delighted. Mozart bows to them, also delighted. Colloredo rises abruptly, and without looking at Mozart or applauding and leaves the Salon. Count Arco approaches the composer. Mozart turns to him, radiant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He follows Arco out of the room, through a throng of admirers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So that was he! That giggling, dirty- minded creature I'd just seen crawling on the floor. Mozart. The phenomenon whose legend had haunted my youth. Impossible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Follow me, please. The Archbishop would like a word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart and Arco walk side by side. They pass Salieri who is staring at Mozart in fascination. As they disappear, he steals toward the music stands, unable to help himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They arrive at the door of Colloredo's private apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arco opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I think that went off remarkably well, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These Viennese certainly know good music when they hear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His Grace is very angry with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are to come in here and ask his pardon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The Archbishop is sitting, chatting to quests. Among them are several ladies. Arco approaches him obsequiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The company watches this scene, deeply interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He extends his hand to be kissed. Mozart does it with a furious grace, then leaves the room. As he opens the door we see:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your Grace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, Mozart. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why what, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do I have to be humiliated in front of my guests by one of my own servants?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Humiliated?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much provocation am I to endure from you? The more license I allow you, the more you take.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If His Grace is not satisfied with me, he can dismiss me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish you to return immediately to Salzburg. Your father is waiting for you there patiently. I will speak to you further when I come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Your Grace! I mean with all humility, no. I would rather you dismissed me. It's obvious I don't satisfy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then try harder, Mozart. I have no intention of dismissing you. You will remain in my service and learn your place. Go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A group of people who have attended the concert, among them Constanze, are standing outside the private apartment. At sight of the composer they break into sustained applause. Mozart is suddenly delighted. He throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop sits - and he can see them. Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee. He smiles and bows uneasily, as they include him in the small ovation. Mozart stands in the corridor, out of the Archbishop's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated, Colloredo signs to Arco, who steps forward and shuts the door, ending the applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Salieri, in this vast room, is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade. He turns the pages back to the slow movement. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri, reading the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination. The music is played against his description of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the music snaps off. Mozart stands before him as he lays down the score.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the score, bows, and struts briskly out of the room. Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Extraordinary! On the page it looked nothing. The beginning simple, almost comic. Just a pulse - bassoons and basset horns - like a rusty squeezebox. Then suddenly - high above it - an oboe, a single note, hanging there unwavering, till a clarinet took over and sweetened it into a phrase of such delight! This was no composition by a performing monkey! This was a music I'd never heard. Filled with such longing, such unfulfillable longing, it had me trembling. It seemed to me that I was hearing a voice of God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI Why?  Would God choose an obscene child to be His instrument? It was not to be believed! This piece had to be an accident. It had to be!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S At the table sits the EMPEROR JOSEPH II, eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent, dapper man of forty, wearing a military uniform. Around him but standing, are his Chamberlain, JOHANN VON STRACK: stiff and highly correct. COUNT ORSINI-ROSENBERG: a corpulent man of sixty, highly conscious of his position as Director of the Opera. BARON VON SWIETEN, the Imperial Librarian: a grave but kindly and educated man in his mid-fifties. FIRST KAPELLMEISTER GIUSEPPE BONNO: very Italian, cringing and time-serving, aged about seventy. And Salieri, wearing decorous black, as usual. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries, using quill pens and inkstands, write down everything of importance that is said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How good is he, this Mozart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's remarkable, Majesty. I heard an extraordinary serious opera of his last month. Idomeneo, King of Crete.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That? A most tiresome piece. I heard it, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tiresome?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A young man trying to impress beyond his abilities. Too much spice. Too many notes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, I thought it the most promising work I've heard in years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Well then, we should make some effort to acquire him. We could use a good German composer in Vienna, surely?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I agree, Majesty, but I'm afraid it's not possible. The young man is still in the pay of the Archbishop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very small pay, I imagine. I'm sure he could be tempted with the right offer. Say, an opera in German for our National Theatre.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent, sire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But not German, I beg your Majesty! Italian is the proper language for opera. All educated people agree on that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. What do you say, Chamberlain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In my opinion, it is time we had a piece in our own language, sir. Plain German. For plain people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Kapellmeister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Italian accent) Majesty, I must agree with Herr Dirretore. Opera is an Italian art, solamente. German is - scusate - too bruta for singing, too rough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Court Composer, what do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it is an interesting notion to keep Mozart in Vienna, Majesty. It should really infuriate the Archbishop beyond measure - if that is your Majesty's intention.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are cattivo, Court Composer. (briskly, to Von Strack) I want to meet this young man. Chamberlain, arrange a pleasant welcome for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. There it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A somber room which serves both as a bedroom and a study. We see a four-poster bed. Also, a marble mantelpiece above which hangs a handsome cross in olivewood, bearing the figure of a severe Christ. Opposite this image sits Salieri at his desk, on which stands a pile of music paper, quill pens and ink. On one side of him is an open forte-piano on which he occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing, with some difficulty. He scratches notes out with his quill, and ruffles his hair - which we see without a powdered wig. There is a knock at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A servant admits LORL, a young lower-class girl, who appears carrying a basket in which is a box covered with a napkin. She has just come from the baker's shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greedily he unwraps the napkin and lifts the lid on the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a biscuit and eats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives a little curtsey, flattered and giggling and is shown out. Salieri turns back to his work, chewing. He plays through a complete line of the march. He smiles, pleased with the result.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He inclines his head to the Christ above the  fireplace, and starts to play the whole march, including the phrase which pleased him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Si.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah! Here she comes. Fraulein Lorl, good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What have you got for me today? Let me see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha! Siena macaroons - my favourites. Give my best thanks to the baker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. Are you well today, Fraulein Lorl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, thank you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bene! Bene!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grazie, Signore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The march continues on the forte-piano as we see Mozart, seated in front of a mirror, wearing an extravagant wig. On either side of him stands a SALESMAN, one of them holding another wig, equally extravagant. Mozart takes off the first wig, to reveal his own blonde hair, of which he is extremely proud, and hands it back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Salesman puts the second wig on his head. Mozart pulls a face of doubt in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes it off and the other Salesman replaces it with the first wig on his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles. The music stops.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And the other one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the other one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, they're both so beautiful, I can't decide. Why don't I have two heads?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A door opens. We glimpse in the next room the Emperor Joseph bidding goodbye to a group of military officers standing around a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and comes into the salon, where another group awaits him. It consists of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten and Salieri. The room contains several gilded chairs dotted about, and a forte-piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All bow and say, Good morning, Your Majesty!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He produces a paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Emperor goes to the instrument, sits and plays the first bars of it. Quite well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Majordomo bows and goes. The Emperor addresses himself to the march. He plays a wrong note.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good, good, good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Von Strack) Well, what do you have for me today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Majesty, Herr Mozart -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, what about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is. Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, I hope you won't think it improper, but I have written a little March of Welcome in his honour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a charming idea. May I see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing it over) It's just a trifle, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I try it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Delightful, Court Composer. Would you permit me to play it as he comes in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do me too much honour, Sire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's have some fun. (to the waiting Majordomo) Bring in Herr Mozart, please. But slowly, slowly. I need a minute to practice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A-flat, Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Taking his instructions literally, the Majordomo is marching very slowly toward the salon door. He is followed by a bewildered Mozart, dressed very stylishly and wearing one of the wigs from the perruqier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Joseph finishes the march. The door opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart comes in eagerly. Immediately the march begins, played by His Majesty. All the courtiers stand, listening with admiration. Joseph plays well, but applies himself fiercely to the manuscript. Mozart, still bewildered, regards the scene, but does not seem to pay attention to the music itself. It finishes and all clap obsequiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Emperor rises, pleased with himself. He snatches the manuscript off the stand and holds it in his hand for the rest of the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He extends his hand. Mozart throws himself to his knees, and to Joseph's discomfort kisses the royal hand with fervour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Embarrassed, Mozart bursts into a wild giggle. Joseph helps him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Von Strack and Bonno nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orsini-Rosenberg nods without enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows elaborately. Salieri inclines himself, dryly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops short with a little giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles again. Orsini-Rosenberg looks at him sourly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Italian faction - Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno - laugh discreetly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An embarrassed pause. Bonno giggles in nervous amusement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Joseph is clearly pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods - he has wanted this result all the time. He turns and makes for the door. All bow. Then he becomes aware of the manuscript in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart does not take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart bows and hands the manuscript back to the Emperor. Then he goes to the forte-piano and seats himself. The others, except for Salieri, gather around the manuscript held by the King. Mozart plays the first half of the march with deadly accuracy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays the first half again but stops in the middle of a phrase, which he repeats dubiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the courtiers look at Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays another phrase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays another phrase. Gradually, he alters the music so that it turns into the celebrated march to be used later in The Marriage of Figaro, Non Piu Andrai. He plays it with increasing abandon and virtuosity. Salieri watches with a fixed smile on his face. The court watches, astonished. He finishes in great glory, takes his hands off the keys with a gesture of triumph - and grins.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bravo, Your Majesty!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well done, Sire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, gentlemen, a little less enthusiasm, I beg you. Ah, Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Majesty!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, please! It is not a holy relic. (raising Mozart up) You know we have met already? In this very room. Perhaps you won't remember it, you were only six years old. (to the others) He was giving the most brilliant little concert here. As he got off the stool, he slipped and fell. My sister Antoinette helped him up herself, and do you know what he did? Jumped straight into her arms and said, Will you marry me, yes or no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know all these gentlemen, I'm sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Baron Von Swieten.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a great admirer of yours, young man. Welcome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Director of our Opera. Count Orsini-Rosenberg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bowing excitedly) Oh sir, yes! The honour is mine. Absolutely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here is our illustrious Court Composer, Herr Salieri.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking his hand) Finally! Such an immense joy. Diletto straordinario!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know your work well, Signore. Do you know I actually composed some variations on a melody of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mio caro Adone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A funny little tune, but it yielded some good things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And now he has returned the compliment. Herr Salieri composed that March of Welcome for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking expertly) Really? Oh, grazie, Signore! Sono commosso! E un onore per mo eccezionale. Compositore brilliante e famossissimo!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there it is. Now to business. Young man, we are going to commission an opera from you. What do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the courtiers) Did we vote in the end for German or Italian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, actually, Sire, if you remember, we did finally incline to Italian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think it was really decided, Director.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, German! German! Please let it be German.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I've already found the most wonderful libretto!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? Have I seen it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - I don't think you have, Herr Director. Not yet. I mean, it's quite n - Of course, I'll show it to you immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you'd better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what is it about? Tell us the story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's actually quite amusing, Majesty. It's set - the  whole thing is set in a - in a -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a Pasha's Harem, Majesty. A Seraglio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean in Turkey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why especially does it have to be in German?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well not especially. It can be in Turkish, if you really want. I don't care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (kindly) My dear fellow, the language is not finally the point. Do you really think that subject is quite appropriate for a national theatre?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? It's charming. I mean, I don't actually show concubines exposing their! their! It's not indecent! (to Joseph) It's highly moral, Majesty. It's full of proper German virtues. I swear it. Absolutely!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm glad to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Sire, but what do you think these could be? Being a foreigner, I would love to learn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cattivo again, Court Composer. Well, tell him, Mozart. Name us a German virtue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Love, Sire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, love! Well of course in Italy we know nothing about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't think you do. I mean watching Italian opera, all those male sopranos screeching. Stupid fat couples rolling their eyes about! That's not love - it's just rubbish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, you choose the language. It will be my task to set it to the finest music ever offered a monarch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there it is. Let it be German.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, this is yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep it, Sire, if you want to. It is already here in my head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? On one hearing only?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so, Sire, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Salieri) The rest is just the same, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That really doesn't work, does it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you try this? Wouldn't it be just a little more -?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or this - yes, this! Better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S We see the olivewood cross. Salieri is sitting at his desk, staring at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a knock at the door. He does not hear it, but sits on. Another knock, louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lorl comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets up and enters:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Grazie, Signore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame Cavalieri is here for her lesson, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bene.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S KATHERINA CAVALIERI, a young, high-spirited soprano of twenty is waiting for him, dressed in a fashionable dress and wearing on her head an exotic turban of satin, with a feather. Lorl exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He seats himself at the forte-piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays a chord. She sings a scale, expertly. He strikes another chord. She starts another scale, then breaks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strikes the chord again, firmly. Cavalieri sings her next scale, then another one, and another one, doing her exercises in earnest. As she hits a sustained high note the orchestral accompaniment in the middle of Martern Aller Arten from Il Seraglio comes in underneath and the music changes from exercises to the exceedingly florid aria. We DISSOLVE on the singer's face, and she is suddenly not merely turbaned, but painted and dressed totally in a Turkish manner, and we are on:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (curtseying to him) Maestro.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (posing, in her turban) Well? How do you like it? It's Turkish. My hairdresser tells me everything's going to be Turkish this year!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? What else did he tell you today? Give me some gossip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I heard you met Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? News travels fast in Vienna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And he's been commissioned to write an opera. Is it true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there a part for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well even if there is, I don't think you want to get involved with this one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, do you know where it's set, my dear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a harem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A brothel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turkish brothel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turkish? Oh, if it's Turkish, that's different. I want to be in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dear, it will hardly enhance your reputation to be celebrated throughout Vienna as a singing prostitute for a Turk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Well perhaps you could introduce us anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does he look like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You might be disappointed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks and talent don't always go together, Katherina.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (airily) Looks don't concern me, Maestro. Only talent interests a woman of taste.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The heroine of the opera (Cavalieri) is in full cry addressing the Pasha with scorn and defiance. The house is full. Watching the performance - which is conducted by Mozart from the clavier in the midst of the orchestra - we note Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno and Von Swieten, all grouped around the Emperor, in a box. In another box we see an overdressed, middle-aged woman and three girls, one of whom is Constanze. This is the formidable MADAME WEBER and her three daughters, Constanze, JOSEFA and SOPHIE. All are enraptured by the spectacle and Madame Weber is especially enraptured by being there at all. Not so, Salieri, who sits in another box, coldly watching the stage. Cavalieri is singing Martern aller Arten from the line Doch du bist entschlossen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a few moments of this showy aria, with the composer and the singer staring at each other - he conducting elaborately for her benefit, and she following his beat with rapturous eyes - the music fades, and Salieri speaks over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Music up again for the last 30 bars of the aria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before the orchestral coda ends, cut to:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Since you are determined, Since you are determined, Calmly, with no ferment, Welcome - every pain and woe. Bind me then - compel me! Bind me then - compel me! Hurt me. Break me! Kill me! At last I shall be freed by death!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) There she was. I had no idea where they met - or how - yet there she stood on stage for all to see. Showing off like the greedy songbird she was. Ten minutes of ghastly scales and arpeggios, whizzing up and down like fireworks at a fairground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Be freed at last by death! Be freed at last by death! At last I shall be freed By! Death!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 Through the window we see that night has fallen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Understand, I was in love with the girl. Or at least in lust. I wasn't a saint. It took me the most tremendous effort to be faithful to my vow. I swear to you I never laid a finger on her. All the same, I couldn't bear to think of anyone else touching her - least of all the Creature.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The brilliant Turkish finale of Seraglio bursts over us. All the cast is lined up on stage. Mozart is conducting with happy excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The curtains fall. Much applause. The Emperor claps vigorously and - following his lead - so do the courtiers. The curtains part. Mozart applauds the singers who applaud him back. He skips up onto the stage amongst them. The curtains fall again as they all bow. In the auditorium, the chandeliers descend, filling it with light.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Pasha Selim May he Live forever! Ever, ever, ever, ever! Honour to his regal name! Honour to his regal name! May his noble brow emblazon Glory, fortune, joy and fame! Honour be to Pasha Selim Honour to his regal name! Honour to his regal name!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The curtains are down, and an excited hubbub of singers in costume surround Mozart and Cavalieri, all excited and chattering. Suddenly a hush. The Emperor is seen approaching from the wings, lit by flunkies holding candles. Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg and Von Swieten, amongst others, follow him. Also Salieri. The singers line up. Joseph stops at Cavalieri who makes a deep curtsey.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bravo, Madame. You are an ornament to our stage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Salieri) And to you, Court Composer. Your pupil has done you great credit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S MADAME WEBER Let us pass, please! Let us pass at once! We're with the Emperor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am sorry, Madame. It is not permitted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who I am? (pointing to Constanze) This is my daughter. I am Frau Weber. We are favoured guests!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am sorry, Madame, but I have my orders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call Herr Mozart! You call Herr Mozart immediately! This is insupportable!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, Constanze. Just ignore this fellow. (pushing her) Go ahead, dear!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barring the way) I am sorry, Madame, but no! I cannot let anyone pass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young man, I am no stranger to theatres. I'm no stranger to insolence!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S All are applauding Cavalieri. The Emperor turns to Mozart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart bows frantically: he is over-excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. General embarrassment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Into this uncomfortable scene bursts a sudden eruption of noise and Madame Weber floods onto the stage, followed by her daughters. All turn to look at this amazing spectacle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves toward Mozart with arms outstretched in an absurd theatrical gesture, then sees the Emperor. She stares at him, mesmerized, her mouth open, unable even to curtsey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart moves forward quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze curtsies. CU, of Cavalieri, astonished at the news. CU, of Salieri, watching her receive it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles uncomfortably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cavalieri is glaring at Mozart. Mozart looks hastily away from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She attempts to kiss the royal hand, but faints instead. The Emperor contemplates her prone body and steps back a pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods pleasantly to all and leaves the stage, with his Chamberlain. All bow. Cavalieri turns with a savage look at Mozart and leaves the stage the opposite way, to her dressing room, tossing her plumed head. Salieri watches. Mozart stays for a second, indecisive whether to follow the soprano or help Madame Weber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurries away. The daughters gather around Madame Weber.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Herr Mozart! A good effort. Decidedly that. An excellent effort! You've shown us something quite new today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is new, it is, isn't it, Sire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, indeed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And German?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes. Absolutely. German. Unquestionably!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So then you like it? You really like it, Your Majesty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I do. It's very good. Of course now and then - just now and then - it gets a touch elaborate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, Sire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I mean occasionally it seems to have, how shall one say? (he stops in difficulty; to Orsini- Rosenberg) How shall one say, Director?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too many notes, Your Majesty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly. Very well put. Too many notes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand. There are just as many notes, Majesty, as are required. Neither more nor less.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dear fellow, there are in fact only so many notes the ear can hear in the course of an evening. I think I'm right in saying that, aren't I, Court Composer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes! yes! er, on  the whole, yes, Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Salieri) But this is absurd!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dear, young man, don't take it too hard. Your work is ingenious. It's quality work. And there are simply too many notes, that's all. Cut a few and it will be perfect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which few did you have in mind, Majesty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. There it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi! Wolfi, my dear!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, this is Madame Weber. She is my landlady.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enchanted, Madame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Sire! such an honour! And, and, and these are my dear daughters. This is Constanze. She is the fiancee of Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? How delightful. May I ask when you marry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well - Well we haven't quite received my father's consent, Your Majesty. Not entirely. Not altogether.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, but how old are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty-six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, my advice is to marry this charming young lady and stay with us in Vienna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see? You see? I've told him that, Your Majesty, but he won't listen to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Your Majesty, you give such wonderful - such impeccable - such royal advice. I - I - May I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. There it is. Strack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mozart) Get some water!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Katherina sits fuming at her mirror. A dresser is taking the pins out of her wig as she stares straight ahead of her. Mozart sticks his head round the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dashes off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Katherina! I'll tell you what I'm going to do. I'm going to write another aria for you. Something even more amazing for the second act. I have to get some water. Her mother is lying on the stage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bother!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Constanze and Mozart make their way quickly through a crowd of actors in turbans and caftans, and stagehands carrying bits of the dismantled set of Seraglio. We see all the turmoil of backstage after a performance. A fireman passes Mozart carrying a small bucket of water. Mozart snatches it from him and pushes his way through the crowd to Madame Weber, who still lies prone on the stage. Mozart pushes through the crowd surrounding her and throws water on her face. She is instantly revived by the shock. Constanze assists her to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Instead of being furious, Madame Weber smiles at them rapturously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The activity continues to swirl around them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, what an evening! What a wise man we have for an Emperor. Oh, my children! (with sudden, hard briskness) Now I want you to write your father exactly what His Majesty said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should really go home now, Frau Weber. Your carriage must be waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But aren't you taking us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to talk to the singers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right; we'll wait for you. Just don't take all night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Cavalieri, still in costume, is marching up and down, very agitated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She catches him looking at her and tries to compose herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart comes in unexpectedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seats herself at her mirror and removes her wig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri looks astonished. There is a knock on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens. Constanze enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart hurries Constanze out of the door. Cavalieri looks after them as they go, her voice breaking and rising out of control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and collapses, crying with rage, into Salieri's arms. We focus on him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know? Had you heard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The marriage!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what does it matter to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing! He can marry who he pleases. I don't give a damn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How was I? Tell me honestly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were sublime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you think of the music?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Extremely clever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meaning you didn't like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh - excuse me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is her mother still lying on the floor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, she's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so relieved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear Mozart, my sincere congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you like it, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could I not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It really is the best music one can hear in Vienna today. Don't you agree?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is she a good fuck?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What??
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I assume she's the virtuoso in that department. There can't be any other reason you'd marry someone like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Wolfi. Mama is not feeling very well. Can we leave now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no, no. You can't take him away now. This is his night. Won't you introduce us, Wolfgang?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse us, Fraulein. Good night, Signore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You really are full of surprises, aren't you? You are quite extraordinary, you little shit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) At that moment I knew beyond any doubt. He'd had her. The Creature had had my darling girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1820'S The old man speaks passionately to the priest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It was incomprehensible. What was God up to? Here I was denying all my natural lust in order to deserve God's gift and there was Mozart indulging his in all directions - even though engaged to be married! - and no rebuke at all! Was it possible I was being tested? Was God expecting me to offer forgiveness in the face of every offense, no matter how painful? That was very possible. All the same, why him? Why use Mozart to teach me lessons in humility? My heart was filling up with such hatred for that little man. For the first time in my life I began to know really violent thoughts. I couldn't stop them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you try?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every day. Sometimes for hours I would pray!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The young Salieri is kneeling in desperation before the Cross.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please! Please! Send him away, back to Salzburg. For his sake as well as mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christ staring from the Cross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S We see Leopold kneeling now not to the Cross but to Archbishop Colloredo, sitting impassively on his throne. Count Arco stands beside him. Leopold is a desperate, once-handsome man of sixty, now far too much the subservient courtier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In deepest gratitude he kisses the Archbishop's hand. He motions Leopold to rise. We hear the first dark fortissimo chord which begins the Overture to Don Giovanni: the theme associated with the character of the Commendatore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The second fortissimo chord sounds.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No! I won't have him back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he needs to be here in Salzburg, Your Grace. He needs me and he needs you. Your protection, your understanding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hardly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh sir, yes! He's about to make the worst mistake of his life. Some little Viennese slut is trying to trick him into marriage. I know my son. He is too simple to see the trap - and there is no one there who really cares for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not surprised. Money seems to be more important to him than loyalty or friendship. He has sold himself to Vienna. Let Vienna look out for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your son is an unprincipled, spoiled, conceited brat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir, that's the truth. But don't blame him. The fault is mine. I was too indulgent with him. But not again. Never again, I promise! I implore you - let me bring him back here. I'll make him give his word to serve you faithfully.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And how will you make him keep it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, sir, he's never disobeyed me in anything. Please, Your Grace, give him one more chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have leave to try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Your Grace - I thank Your Grace! I thank you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) My dear son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S We see a huge CU, of Mozart's head, looking front and down, as if reading his father's letter. We hear Leopold's voice over this image, no longer whining and anxious, but impressive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera pulls back to see that he is in fact kneeling beside Constanze. A PRIEST faces them. Behind them are Madame Weber, Josefa and Sophie Weber, and a very few others. Among them, a merry looking lady in bright clothes: the BARONESS WALDSTADTEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The opening kyrie of the great Mass in C Minor is heard. Mozart and Constanze kiss. They are in tears. Madame Weber and her daughters look on approvingly. The music swells and continues under the following:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I write to you with urgent news. I am coming to Vienna. Take no further steps toward marriage until we meet. You are too gullible to see your own danger. As you honour the father who has devoted his entire life to yours, do as I bid, and await my coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And will you, Constanze Weber, take this man, Wolfgang to be your lawful husband?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I now pronounce you man and wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S There is a view of a castle in background. Leopold sits alone in his room. He is reading a letter from Wolfgang. At his feet are his trunks, half-packed for the journey he will not now take. We hear Mozart's voice reading the following letter and we see, as the camera roves around the room, mementos of the young prodigy's early life: the little forte-piano made for him; the little violin made for him; an Order presented to him. We see a little starling in a wicker cage. And we see portraits of the boy on the walls, concluding with the familiar family portrait of Wolfgang and his sister Nannerl seated at the keyboard with Leopold standing, and the picture of their mother on the wall behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music of the Mass fades as Leopold crumples the letter in his hand.
