direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Most beloved father, it is done. Do not blame me that I did not wait to see your dear face. I knew you would have tried to dissuade me from my truest happiness and I could not have borne it. Your every word is precious to me. Remember how you have always told me Vienna is the City of Musicians. To conquer here is to conquer Europe! With my wife I can do it.  I vow I will become regular in my habits and productive as never before. She is wonderful, Papa, and I know that you will love her. And one day soon when I am a wealthy man, you will come and live with us, and we will be so happy. I long for that day, best of Papas, and kiss your hand a hundred thousand times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Salieri stands waiting, hat in hand. Beside him stands a royal servant. Behind him, gardeners are glimpsed tending the shrubs and bushes along a grassy ride. Down this ride are seen cantering two people on horseback: the Emperor Joseph and his niece, the PRINCESS ELIZABETH. They are mounted on glossy horses. The Princess rides side-saddle. Running beside her is a panting groom. The Emperor rides elegantly; his niece, a dumpy little Hapsburg girl of sixteen, like a sack of potatoes. As they draw level with Salieri they stop, and the groom holds the head of the Princess' horse. Salieri bows respectfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out of breath, the Princess nods nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles at Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri's face falls, almost imperceptibly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rides on. The groom releases her horse's head, and runs on after the Princess.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Court Composer. This is my niece, the Princess Elizabeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Highness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She has asked me to advise her on a suitable musical instructor. I think I've come up with an excellent idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Your Majesty, it would be such a tremendous honour!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm thinking about Herr Mozart. What is your view?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An interesting idea, Majesty. But -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You already commissioned an opera from Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the result satisfies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course. My concern is to protect you from any suspicion of favouritism.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Favouritism. But I so want Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure there is a way, Majesty. Some kind of a little contest. I could perhaps put together a small Committee, and I could see to it naturally that it will select according to Your Majesty's wishes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You please me, Court Composer. A very clever idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bowing) Sire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. There it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Von Strack sits stiffly behind his gilded desk. Mozart stands before him, trembling with anger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this, Herr Chamberlain?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do I have to submit samples of my work to some stupid committee? Just to teach a sixteen-year-old girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because His Majesty wishes it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is the Emperor angry with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the contrary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why doesn't he simply appoint me to the post?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart, you are not the only composer in Vienna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I'm the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little modesty would suit you better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is on this committee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kapellmeister Bonno, Count Orsini- Rosenberg and Court Composer Salieri.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naturally, the Italians! Of course! Always the Italians!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They hate my music. It terrifies them. The only sound Italians understand is banality. Tonic and dominant, tonic and dominant, from here to Resurrection! (singing angrily) Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Ba-ba! Anything else is morbid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show them one interesting modulation and they faint. Ohime! Morbidezza! Morbidezza! Italians are musical idiots and you want them to judge my music!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, young man, the issue is simple. If you want this post, you must submit your stuff in the same way as all your colleagues.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must I? Well, I won't! I tell you straight: I will not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The room is very small and untidy. Constanze is marching up and down it, upset. Mozart is lying on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glares at him, almost in tears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think you're mad! You're really mad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, leave me alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One royal pupil and the whole of Vienna will come flocking. We'd be set up for life!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll come anyway. They love me here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, they will not. I know how things work in this city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes? You always know everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm not borrowing any more money from my mother, and that's that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You borrowed money from your mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, don't do that again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How are we going to live, Wolfi? Do you want me to go into the streets and beg?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All they want to see is your work. What's wrong with that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up! Just shut up! I don't need them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't pride. It's sheer stupidity!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - 1780'S Salieri is giving a lesson to a girl student, who is singing the Italian art song, Caro Mio Ben. There is a knock on the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri goes into the salon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir, there is a lady who insists on talking to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She didn't say. But she says it's urgent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the pupil) Excuse me, my dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - 1780'S Constanze stands, closely veiled, holding a portfolio stuffed with manuscripts. The singing lesson ends, with two chords on the instrument. Salieri enters the salon. Constanze drops him a shy curtsey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shyly, she unveils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the portfolio and puts it on a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A short pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He indicates a dish piled high with glazed chestnuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers her the dish. She takes one and puts it in her mouth. He watches carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes one himself. We notice on his finger a heavy gold signet-ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles at her. She takes another chestnut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause. He puts out his hand and takes up the portfolio from the table. He opens it. He looks at the music. He is puzzled.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excellency!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame. How can I help you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frau Mozart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, Your Excellency. I've come on behalf of my hus band. I'm - I'm bringing some samples of his work so he can be considered for the royal appointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How charming.  But why did he not come himself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's terribly busy, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will look at them, of course, the moment I can. It will be an honour. Please give him my warmest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would it be too much trouble, sir, to ask you to look at them now? While I wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I'm not at leisure this very moment. Just leave them with me. I assure you they will be quite safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - I really cannot do that, Your Excellency. You see, he doesn't know I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My husband is a proud man, sir. He would be furious if he knew I'd come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then he didn't send you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir. This is my own idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, we really need this job. We're desperate. My husband spends far more than he can ever earn. I don't mean he's lazy - he's not at all - he works all day long. It's just! he's not practical. Money simply slips through his fingers, it's really ridiculous, Your Excellency. I know you help musicians. You're famous for it. Give him just this one post. We'd be forever indebted!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me offer you some refreshment. Do you know what these are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cappezzoli di Venere. Nipples of Venus. Roman chestnuts in brandied sugar. Won't you try one? They're quite surprising.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! They're wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much, Your Excellency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't keep calling me that. It puts me at such a distance. I was not born a Court Composer, you know. I'm from a small town, just like your husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure you can't leave that music, and come back again? I have other things you might like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's very tempting, but it's impossible, I'm afraid. Wolfi would be frantic if he found those were missing. You see, they're all originals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Originals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are originals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. He doesn't make copies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 The old man faces the Priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vogler stares at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Astounding! It was actually beyond belief. These were first and only drafts of music yet they showed no corrections of any kind. Not one. Do you realize what that meant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'd simply put down music already finished in his head. Page after page of it, as if he was just taking dictation. And music finished as no music is ever finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATE AFTERNOON - 1780'S CU, The manuscript in Mozart's handwriting. The music begins to sound under the following:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music swells. What we now hear is an amazing collage of great passages from Mozart's music, ravishing to Salieri and to us. The Court Composer, oblivious to Constanze, who sits happily chewing chestnuts, her mouth covered in sugar, walks around and around his salon, reading the pages and dropping them on the floor when he is done with them. We see his agonized and wondering face: he shudders as if in a rough and tumbling sea; he experiences the point where beauty and great pain coalesce. More pages fall than he can read, scattering across the floor in a white cascade, as he circles the room. Finally, we hear the tremendous Qui Tollis from the Mass in C Minor. It seems to break over him like a wave and, unable to bear any more of it, he slams the portfolio shut. Instantly, the music breaks off, reverberating in his head. He stands shaking, staring wildly. Constanze gets up, perplexed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri tries to recover himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Overjoyed, she stops and kisses his hand. He raises her - and then clasps her to him clumsily. She pushes herself away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stare at one another: Constanze in total disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rings a silver bell for a servant and abruptly leaves the roam. Constanze stares after him, horrified. The servant enters. Shocked and stunned, Constanze goes down an her knees and starts picking up the music from the floor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Displace one note and there would be diminishment. Displace one phrase, and the structure would fall. It was clear to me. That sound I had heard in the Archbishop's palace had been no accident. Here again was the very voice of God! I was staring through the cage of those meticulous ink- strokes at an absolute, inimitable beauty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it no good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is miraculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes. He's really proud of his work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, will you help him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow night I dine with the Emperor. One word from me and the post is his.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, thank you, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come back tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some service deserves service in return. No?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't it obvious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a post all Vienna seeks. If you want it for your husband, come tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But! I'm a married woman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then don't. It's up to you. Not to be vague, that is the price.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 CU, Father Vogler, horrified.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Father. Yes! So much for my vow of chastity. What did it matter? Good, patient, hard-working, chaste - what did it matter? Had goodness made me a good composer? I realized it absolutely then - that moment: goodness is nothing in the furnace of art. And I was nothing to God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crying out) You cannot say that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No? Was Mozart a good man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God's ways are not yours. And you are not here to question Him. Offer him the salt of penitence. He will give you back the bread of eternal life. He is all merciful. That is all you need to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I ever wanted was to sing to Him. That's His doing, isn't it? He gave me that longing - then made me mute. Why? Tell me that. If He didn't want me to serve Him with music, why implant the desire, like a lust in my body, then deny me the talent? Go on, tell me! Speak for Him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My son, no one can speak for God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh? I thought you did so every day. So speak now. Answer me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not claim to unravel the mysteries. I treasure them. As you should.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatiently) Oh yes, yes, yes, yes, yes! Always the same stale answers! (intimately to the priest) There is no God of Mercy, Father. Just a God of torture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Salieri sits at his desk, staring up at the cross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long, long silence. Salieri stares at the cross. Christ stares back at him impassively. Finally in this silence we hear a faint knocking at the door. Salieri stirs himself. A servant appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Servant bows and leaves. We follow him through:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Evening came to that room. I sat there not knowing whether the girl would return or not. I prayed as I'd never prayed before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear God, enter me now. Fill me with one piece of true music. One piece with your breath in it, so I know that you love me. Please. Just one. Show me one sign of your favour, and I will show mine to Mozart and his wife. I will get him the royal position, and if she comes, I'll receive her with all respect and send her home in joy. Enter me! Enter me! Please! Te imploro.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That lady is back, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show her in. Then go to bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The Servant crosses it and enters:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Constanze is sitting on an upright chair, veiled as before, the portfolio of music on her lap. Through the far door leading from the hall, another servant is peering at her. The first servant joins him and shuts the door on the girl, leaving her alone. We stay with her. The clock ticks on the mantelpiece. We hear an old carriage pass in the street below. Nervously she lifts her veil and looks about her. Suddenly Salieri appears from the music room. He is pale and very tight. They regard each other. She smiles and rises to greet him, affecting a relaxed and warm manner, as if to put him at his ease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she talks, she extinguishes the candles in a pair of Venetian candelabra and subsequently other candles around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and takes off her shawl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She picks up the portfolio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him inquiringly, and drops the portfolio on the floor; pages of music pour out of it. Instantly we hear a massive chord, and the great Qui Tollis from the Mass in C Minor fills the room. To its grand and weighty sound, Constanze starts to undress, watched by the horrified Salieri. Between him and her, music is an active presence, hurting and baffling him. He opens his mouth in distress. The music pounds in his head. The candle flickers over her as she removes her clothes and prepares for his embrace. Suddenly he cries out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snatches up the bell and shakes it frantically, not stopping until the two servants we saw earlier appear at the door. The music stops abruptly. They stare at the appalled and frightened Constanze, who is desperately trying to cover her nakedness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze hurls herself at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He seizes her wrists and thrusts her back. Then he leaves the room quickly, slamming the door behind him. Constanze turns and sees the two servants goggling at her in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wildly, she picks up the candelabrum and throws it at them. It shatters on the floor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm here. My husband has gone to a concert. He didn't think I would enjoy it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do apologize for this afternoon. I behaved like a silly girl. Where shall we go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should we stay here? It's a charming room. I love these candlesticks. Were they here earlier? I didn't notice them I suppose I was too nervous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfgang was given some candlesticks by King George in England, but they were only wood. Oh, excuse me. Let's not talk about him. What do you think of this? It's real lace. Brussels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's much too good for every day. I keep saying to Wolfi, don't be so extravagant. Presents are lovely, but we can't afford them. It doesn't do any good. The more I tell him, the more he spends. Oh, excuse me! There I go again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you still want to look at this? Or don't we need to bother anymore? I imagine we don't, really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go! Go! Go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show this woman out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shit! You shit! You rotten shit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you staring at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S CU, Salieri standing, his eyes shut, shaking in distress. He opens them and sees Christ across the room, staring at him from the wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) From now on, we are enemies, You and I!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 The old man is reliving the experience. Vogler looks at him, horrified.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Because You will not enter me, with all my need for you; because You scorn my attempts at virtue; because You choose for Your instrument a boastful, lustful, smutty infantile boy and give me for reward only the ability to recognize the Incarnation; because You are unjust, unfair, unkind, I will block You! I swear it! I will hinder and harm Your creature on earth as far as I am able. I will ruin Your Incarnation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S CU, the fireplace. In it lies the olivewood Christ on the cross, burning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cross flames up and disintegrates. Salieri stares at it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) What use after all is Man, if not to teach God His lessons?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The front door bursts open. Mozart stumbles in, followed by EMMANUEL SCHIKANEDER, three young actresses, and another man, all fairly drunk. Schikaneder (who appears everywhere accompanied by young girls) is a large, fleshy, extravagant man of about thirty-five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks unsteadily to the bedroom door and opens it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stanzi! Stanzi! Stanzi-Manzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (imitating Mozart) Stanzi-Manzi-Banzi-Wanzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh! Stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the girls, very tipsy) Sssh! You're dishgrashful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Constanze lies in bed, her back turned to her husband, who comes into the room and shuts the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns around abruptly. She looks dreadful; her eyes red with weeping. Mozart is shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He approaches the bed and sits on it. Immediately she starts crying again, desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds her and she clings to him in a fierce embrace, crying a flood of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts crying again, throwing her arms around his neck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (playfully) Stanzi? How's my mouse? Mouse-wouse? I'm back - puss-wuss is back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stanzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? What is it? Stanzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it now. Stop it. I've brought some friends to meet you. They're next door waiting. Do we have anything to eat? They're all starving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell them to go away. I don't want to see anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell them to go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sssh. What is it? Tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you! I love you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you. Please stay with me. I'm frightened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Joseph sits eating. A butler serves him goat's milk to drink. Joseph is holding a memorandum from Salieri in his hand. Salieri stands before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a gesture Joseph dismisses the butler, who bows and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think you understand me, Court Composer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, I did. Believe me, it was a most agonizing. decision. But finally, I simply could not recommend Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Sire, I made some inquiries in a routine way. I was curious to know why he had so few pupils. It is rather alarming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, I don't like to talk against a fellow musician.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to tell you, Mozart is not entirely to be trusted alone with young ladies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As a matter of fact, one of my own pupils - a very young singer - told me she was - er - well!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Molested, Majesty. Twice, in the course of the same lesson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Salieri has just returned from the palace and is coming up the staircase. He is met by his servant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri is plainly alarmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He mounts the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, there is a Herr Mozart waiting for you in the salon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does he want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't say, sir. I told him I didn't know when you would be back, but he insisted on waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come with me. And stay in the room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart is waiting for Salieri, holding a portfolio. Salieri approaches him nervously. Mozart stands not belligerently, but humbly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri looks at him in distress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart chuckles delightedly. Salieri offers him a glass of white dessert and a spoon. Mozart takes it absently and goes on talking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart, what brings you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Excellency, you requested some specimens of my work. Here they are. I don't have to tell you how much I need your help. I truly appreciate your looking at these. I have pressures on me - financial pressures. As you know, I'm a married man now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you are. How is your pretty wife?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She is well. She is - well, actually, I'm about to become a father! She only told me last night. You are the first to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm flattered. And congratulations to you, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you see, this post is very important to me right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you come to me yesterday, Mozart? This is a most painful situation. Yesterday I could have helped you. Today, I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Here is the music. It's here. I am submitting it humbly. Isn't that what you wanted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have just come from the palace. The post has been filled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Filled? That's impossible! They haven't even seen my work. I need this post. Please, can't you help me? Please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dear Mozart, there is no one in the world I would rather help, but now it is too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whom did they choose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Sommer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sommer? Herr Sommer? But the man's a fool! He's a total mediocrity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no: he has yet to achieve mediocrity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I can't lose this post, I simply can't! Excellency, please. Let's go to the palace, and you can explain to the Emperor that Herr Sommer is an awful choice. He could actually do musical harm to the Princess!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An implausible idea. Between you and me, no one in the world could do musical harm to the Princess Elizabeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I must have pupils. Without pupils I can't manage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't mean to tell me you are living in poverty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but I'm broke. I'm always broke. I don't know why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It has been said, my friend, that you are inclined to live somewhat above your means.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can anyone say that? We have no cook, no maid. We have no footman. Nothing at all!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is that possible? You give concerts, don't you? I hear they are quite successful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're stupendously successful. You can't get a seat. The only problem is none will hire me. They all want to hear me play, but they won't let me teach their daughters. As if I was some kind of fiend. I'm not a fiend!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have a daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, could you lend me some money till you have one? Then I'll teach her for free. That's a promise. Oh, I'm sorry. I'm being silly. Papa's right - I should put a padlock on my mouth. Seriously, is there any chance you could manage a loan? Only for six months, eight at most. After that I'll be the richest man in Vienna. I'll pay you back double. Anything. Name your terms. I'm not joking. I'm working on something that's going to explode like a bomb all over Europe!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, how exciting! Tell me more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd better not. It's a bit of a secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come, come, Mozart; I'm interested. Truly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, it's a big secret. Oh, this is delicious! What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cream cheese mixed with granulated sugar and suffused with rum. Crema al Mascarpone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah. Italian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive me. We all have patriotic feelings of some kind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two thousand, two hundred florins is all I need A hundred? Fifty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What exactly are you working on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't say. Really
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think you should become known in Vienna as a debtor, Mozart. However, I know a very distinguished gentleman I could recommend to you. And he has a daughter. Will that do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MORNING - 1780'S Hysterical barking and howling. The hall is full of dogs, at least five, all jumping up and dashing about and making a terrific racket. Mozart, dandified in a new coat and a plumed hat for the occasion, has arrived to teach at the house of a prosperous merchant, MICHAEL SCHLUMBERG. Bluff, friendly and coarse-looking, he stands in his hall amidst the leaping and barking animals, greeting Mozart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads Mozart through the throng of dogs into a salon furnished with comfortable middle-class taste.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Quiet! Quiet! Quiet! Down there, damn you. (to Mozart) Welcome to you. Pay no attention, they're impossible. Stop it, you willful things! Come this way. Just ignore them. They're perfectly harmless, just willful. I treat them just like my own children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And which one of them do you want me to teach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Ha-ha! That's funny - I like it. Which one, eh? You're a funny fellow. (shouting) Hannah! Come this way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hannah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: appears: an anxious woman in middle life.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mozart) You won't be teaching this one either. She's my wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bowing) Madame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Herr Mozart, my dear. The young man Herr Salieri recommended to teach our Gertrude. Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Upstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gertrude!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't be Herr Mozart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, it's him. Who do you think it is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard about you for ages! I thought you must be an old man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gertrude!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's such an honour for us to have you here, Herr Mozart. And for Gertrude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People who know say the girl's got talent. You must judge for yourself. If you think she stinks, say so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Michael, please! I'm sure you will find her most willing, Herr Mozart. She's really very excited. She's been preparing all morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, now! Here she comes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: appears in the doorway: an awkward girl of fifteen in her best dress, her hair primped and curled. She is exceedingly nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gertrude giggles instead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads the way into:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Fraulein Schlumberg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Strudel, this is Herr Mozart. Say good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mozart) Perhaps a little refreshment first? A little coffee, or a little chocolate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like a little wine, if you have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite right. He's going to need it. (calling and clapping his hands) Klaus! A bottle of wine. Prestissimo! Now let's go to it. I've been waiting all day for this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A forte-piano is open and waiting. All the dogs follow him. After them come Mozart Frau and Fraulein Schlumberg. To Mozart's dismay, husband and wife seat themselves quite formally on a little narrow sofa, side by side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dogs settle at their feet. Husband and wife smile encouragingly at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart gestures to the music bench. Reluctantly, the girl sits at the instrument. Mozart sits beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In response the wretched girl just stares down at the keyboard without playing a note. An awkward pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Husband and wife look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. The girl sits unmoving. Schlumberg bellows:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the girl rises. Mozart smiles at the parents. They smile nervously back. Mozart slides along the bench, raises his hands and preludes over the keys. Instantly a dog howls loudly. Startled, Mozart stops. Schlumberg leaps to his feet and goes over to the beagle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart resumes playing. This time it is a lively piece, perhaps the Presto Finale from the K. 450. The dog howls immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amazed, Mozart starts to play the Rondo again. The dog howls louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart plays on. Suddenly the dog falls silent. Schlumberg smiles broadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wife scurries to get a jar of biscuits. A servant brings in an open bottle of wine and a full glass on a tray. He puts it down beside Mozart as Schlumberg addresses the silent dog with deepest affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives the biscuit to the dog who swallows it greedily. Mozart stops playing and stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows to them and leaves the room. They look after him in puzzled astonishment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (To the dogs) Now sit down all of you and behave. Zeman, Mandi, absolutely quiet! (to a young beagle) Especially you, Dudelsachs - not one sound from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, then. Up and at it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, please play me something. Just to give me an idea. Anything will do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to parents) I don't want you to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right, dear. Just go ahead, as if we weren't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you are here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind, Strudel. It's part of music, getting used to an audience. Aren't I right, Herr Mozart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yes! on the whole. I suppose. (to Gertrude) How long have you been playing, Fraulein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just one year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who was your teacher?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was. But she quite outgrew the little I could show her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Madame. (to Gertrude) Come on now - courage. Play me something you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps it would be better if we were left alone. I think we're both a little shy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense. Strudel's not shy. She's just willful! You give into her now, you'll be sorry later. Strudel - play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said play!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Michael!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps if I were to play a little first, it might encourage the Fraulein. (to the girl) Why don't you let me try the instrument? All right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop that, Dudelsachs! Stop it at once! (to Mozart) Don't let him disturb you. He'll be all right. He's just a little willful too. Please, please - play. I beg you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it! STOP!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, not you. I was talking to the dog. You keep playing. It's most important. He always howls when he hears music. We've got to break them of the habit. Play, please. Please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. Now keep going, just keep going. (to the beagle) Now you stop that noise, Dudelsachs, you stop it this instant! This instant, do you hear me? Keep going, Herr Mozart, that's it. Go on, go on!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, good, good! Very good dog! Very, very good Dudelsachs. (to his wife, snapping his fingers) Quick, quick, dear, bring his biscuit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now guess who's going to get a nice reward? Clever, clever Dudi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a miracle, Herr Mozart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely controlling himself) Well, I'm a good teacher. The next time you wish me to instruct another of your dogs, please let me know. Goodbye, Fraulein, goodbye, Madame! goodbye, Sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a strange young man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. He is a little strange.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A cheerful scene. We see Mozart strutting and beaming, making his way through the crowd of porters, carriers and hawkers, sellers of sausages and pastries, vendors of hats and ribbons. Horses and carriage clatter past him. His mood is best expressed by a bubbling version of Non piu Andrai played on the forte-piano. Still in the same mood, he enters the door of his own house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Suddenly, he stops. He looks up the stairs. The grim opening chords from the Overture to Don Giovanni cut across the march from Figaro. What he sees, looking up the stairs, is a menacing figure in a long, grey cape and dark grey hat, standing on the landing. The light comes from behind the figure so that we see only its silhouette as it unfolds its arms towards Mozart in an alarming gesture of possession. It takes a beat in which the air of sinister mystery is held before Mozart realizes who it is. Then, as the music continues, he hastily sets down the bottle of wine and rushes joyfully up the stairs and hurls himself into the figure's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both men embrace. The music slowly fades.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Papa! PAPA!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A cramped, low-ceilinged little room which nobody has tidied for ages. We see music lying everywhere. Also there are many empty wine bottles; musical instruments - among them a mandolin, a viola, a forte-piano with the black and white keys reversed - books and abandoned plates of food. Mozart clasps his father's arms. Leopold is now seen as an aging, travel-stained man in clothes that need repair. His face is lined, and he is obviously not in perfect health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kisses his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart ducks away and fetches his father's bags from the landing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leopold looks about him at the mess in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He carries the bag across the room and opens the door of the bedroom. Constanze lies in bed. She sits up, startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze, who looks ill and tired, stares at Leopold. Leopold stares back from the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes the door again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up some pages of manuscript.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze comes into the room. She is wearing a dressing gown and has made a perfunctory attempt to tidy her hair. We see that she is clearly pregnant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives a little giggle of embarrassment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jaunty tune of Ich Mochte Wohl Der Kaiser sein (K.539) sounds through all the following. This is an alternate song from Il Seraglio: a very extroverted tune for baritone and orchestra and a prominent part for bass drum. The vocal part should be arranged for trumpet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I not welcome?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, welcome! Welcome ten thousand times. Papa! my Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're very thin. Does she not feed you, this wife of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Feed? Well, of course she feeds me. She stuffs me like a goose all day long. She's the best cook in the world. I mean, since Mama. Just wait, you'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is she not here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Stanzi? Stanzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you always live like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes. Oh, I mean no - not exactly like this. I mean today - just today, Stanzi - I remember now. She had to go - yes! She had to help her mother. Yes, she's like that. Her mother's a very sweet woman, you'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! I didn't know you were home. Stanzi, this is my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll wait, we'll wait. Why don't you get up now, darling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's very tired, poor creature. You know me: I'm a real pig. It's not so easy cleaning up after me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you have a maid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh we could, if we wanted to, but Stanzi won't hear of it. She wants to do everything herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is your financial situation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It couldn't be better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not what I hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean? It's wonderful. Really, it's - it's marvelous! People love me here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They say you're in debt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who? Who says that? Now that's a malicious lie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many pupils do you have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pupils?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. It's not important. I mean, I don't want pupils. They get in the way. I've got to have time for composition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Composition doesn't pay. You know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This one will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, let's not talk about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have secrets from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too dangerous, Papa. But they're going to love it. Ah, there she is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My Stanzi - look at her! Isn't she beautiful? Come on now, confess, Papa. Could you want a prettier girl for a daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it, Wolfi. I look dreadful. Welcome to our house, Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not Herr Mozart. Call him Papa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see that you're expecting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When, may I ask?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In three months! Papa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't that marvelous? We're delighted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you mention it in your letters?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't I? I thought I did. I'm sure I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I offer you some tea, Herr Mozart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tea? Who wants tea? Let's go out! This calls for a feast. You don't want tea, Papa. Let's go dancing. Papa loves parties, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? How can you be so boring? Tea!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi, I think your father's tired. I'll cook us something here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. That'll be fine. Don't spend any money on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? Oh, come, Papa! What better way could I spend it than on you? My kissable, missable, suddenly visible Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart and Constanze with Leopold between them. We see couples shopping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S This is a shop where one can buy costumes for masquerades. It is filled with extravagant costumes of various kinds. Wolfgang is wearing a costume, a mask pushed up on his forehead; Constanze is wearing a little white velvet mask. Amidst the merriment, Leopold is helped by two assistants to put on a dark grey cloak and a dark grey tricorne hat, to which is attached a full mask of dark grey. Its mouth is cut into a fixed upward smile. He turns and looks at his son through this mask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S We are in the full whirl of a Masquerade Ball. Couples are dancing around dressed in fantastic costumes. The music of Ich Mochte Wohl Der Kaiser sein increases in volume and persists. We see the musicians thumping it out on a balustrade above the dancers. A steer is being roasted. Through the bobbing crowd we see a group, headed by the figure of Bacchus: this is Schikaneder in a Greek costume, wearing vine leaves in his hair. He is accompanied by his usual trio of actresses and three other men. Constanze as Columbine and Mozart as Harlequin are pulling Leopold by the hand of his dark cloak and smiling mask. This whole group threads its way across the crowded room and disappears through a door. As they go, they are watched by Salieri, standing alone in a corner, wearing ordinary evening clothes. He turns away hastily to avoid being seen by them. As soon as they disappear into the far room, Salieri goes quickly to a lady in the corner who is giving guests domino masks off a tray. He quickly takes a small black mask and puts it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S A fantastic room designed as a rocky grotto, lit by candles. A forte-piano to one side is being played by Schikaneder: the music of Ich Mochte Wohl Der Kaiser sein cross-fades to another tune.  This is Vivat Bacchus from Il Seraglio which Schikaneder, dressed as Bacchus, is humming as he plays. The music is actually accompanying a game of Forfeits, which has begun. Five couples (the group we have just seen) are dancing in the middle of a ring made by nine chairs. When the music stops they will each have to find a chair, and the one who fails must pay a forfeit. Constanze is dancing with Leopold; Mozart is dancing with one of the actresses; the two other actresses are dancing with two other gentlemen; and two children dance together - a little boy and a little girl. The scene is watched by a circle of bystanders; among them - from the doorway - is Salieri. Schikaneder stops playing. Immediately the couples scramble for the chairs. Leopold and Constanze meet on the same chair, bumping and pushing at each other to get sole possession of it. To the amusement of the people around, the chair over- balances and they both end up on the floor. Constanze immediately gets up again, sets the chair on its feet, and tries to pretend she was sitting in it all the time. But Schikaneder calls out from the forte-piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People are delighted by the idea of this penalty. The children jump up and down with excitement. The three actresses immediately surround Leopold, reaching for his hat and mask and wig, whilst he tries to hold on to them. Mozart takes off Constanze's wig - an absurd affair with side-curls. Constanze laughingly surrenders it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Despite his protests an actress takes off his hat, to which the smiling mask is attached, to reveal his outraged face showing a very different expression underneath. Another actress snatches off his wig to reveal very sparse hair on the old man's head. The third actress takes Constanze's wig from Mozart and attempts to put it on his father's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze echoes him with a touch of malice in her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughingly, the bystanders take it up, especially the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Leopold glares furiously about him, the actress succeeds in getting Constanze's wig firmly onto his head. Everybody bursts into applause. Delightedly, Constanze puts on Leopold's wig, hat and mask: from the waist up she now looks like a weird parody of Leopold in the smiling grey mask, and he looks like a weird parody of her in the silly feminine wig. Schikaneder starts to play again, and the couples start to dance. Leopold angrily takes off Constanze's wig and leaves the circle; his partner, Constanze, is left alone. Seeing this, Mozart leaves his partner and catches his father entreatingly by the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes off his own wig and puts it on Leopold's uncovered head. The effect, if not as ridiculous, is still somewhat bizarre, since Wolfgang favours fairly elaborate wigs. He takes Constanze's wig from his father. As this happens, the music stops again. Mozart gently pushes his father down onto a nearby chair; the others scramble for the other chairs; and he is left as the Odd Man Out. He giggles. Schikaneder calls out to Leopold from the keyboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the bystanders are watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart runs over to the forte-piano, and Schikaneder surrenders his place at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amused sounds of disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Renewed applause at this wicked extra penalty. Mozart smiles at Schikaneder - it is the sort of challenge he loves. He defiantly puts on Constanze's wig and seats himself with his back to the keyboard. Before the astonished eyes of the company he proceeds to execute this absurdly difficult task. His right hand plays the bass part, his left hand the treble, and with this added difficulty he improvises a brilliant fugue on the subject of the tune to which they have been dancing. Attracted by this astonishing feat, the players draw nearer to the instrument. So does Salieri, cautiously, with some of the bystanders. Constanze watches him approach. Only Leopold sits by himself, sulking. The fugue ends amidst terrific clapping. The guests call out to Mozart.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, no! You both lost. You both lost. You both have to forfeit. And the penalty is you must exchange your wigs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, please! This is ridiculous! No, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, really!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling to him) This is just a game, Papa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is just a game, Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is just a game, Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, Papa, please! Don't spoil the fun. Come on. Here, take mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart, why don't you name your son's penalty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Papa, name it. Name it. I'll do anything you say!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to come back with me to Salzburg, my son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did he say? What did he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Papa, the rule is you can only give penalties that can be performed in the room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm tired of this game. Please play without me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But my penalty. I've got to have a penalty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a good one. I've got the perfect one for you. Come over here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, I want you to play our tune - sitting backwards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's really too easy. Any child can do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And a fugue in the manner of Sebastian Bach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another! Do another! Someone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me a name. Who shall I do? Give me a name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gluck! Haydn! Frederic Handel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salieri! Do Salieri!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Salieri's masked face whips around and looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Giggling, he turns around and sits at the keyboard. Then, watched by a highly amused group, he begins a wicked parody. He furrows his brow in mock concentration and closes his eyes. Then he begins to play the tune to which they danced, in the most obvious way imaginable, relying heavily on a totally and offensively unimaginative bass of tonic and dominant, endlessly repeated. The music is the very essence of banality. The bystanders rock with laughter. Mozart starts to giggle wildly. Through this excruciating scene, Salieri stares at Constanze, who suddenly turns her head and looks challengingly back at him. Mozart's parody reaches its coarse climax with him adding a fart noise instead of notes to end cadences. He builds this up, urged on in his clowning by everyone else, until suddenly he stops and cries out. The laughter cuts off. Mozart stands up, clutching his behind as if he has made a mess in his breeches. The momentary hush of alarm is followed by a howl of laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now that's hard. That's very hard. For Salieri one has to face the right way around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Salieri staring in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 CU, The old man is shaking at the very recollection of his humiliation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go on. Mock me. Laugh, laugh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S A repetition of the shot of Mozart at the forte-piano, wearing Constanze's wig and emitting a shrill giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Salieri sits at his desk. He holds in his hand the small black party mask and stares in hatred at the place on the wall where the crucifix used to hang. Faintly we see the mark of the cross.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) That was not Mozart laughing, Father. That was God. That was God! God laughing at me through that obscene giggle. Go on, Signore. Laugh. Rub my nose in it. Show my mediocrity for all to see. You wait! I will laugh at You! Before I leave this earth, I will laugh at You! Amen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S It is littered with manuscripts. In the middle stands a billiard table. The beautiful closing ensemble from Act IV of Figaro: Ah, Tutti contenti! Saremo cosi plays in the background. Standing at the billiard table, Mozart is dreamily hearing the music and playing shots on the table. From time to time he drifts over to a piece of manuscript paper and jots down notes. He is very much in his own world of composition and the billiard balls are an aid to creation. Presently, however, we hear a knocking at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music breaks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (outside the door) Wolfi! Wolfgang!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a young girl to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does she want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, ask her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She won't talk to me. She says she has to speak to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, damn!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart comes out. Framed in the doorway from outside stands Lorl, the maid we noticed in Salieri's house. From his bedroom Leopold peeps out to watch. Mozart goes to the girl. Constanze follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart turns to his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man emerges from his bedroom. His son looks at him delightedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze looks furiously at him, then at Lorl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lorl goes outside and closes the door. Constanze turns on Leopold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Explosively she opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leads the maid into Leopold's room. Mozart steals back into his workroom and gently closes the door. Leopold is left alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you Herr Mozart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Lorl, sir. I'm a maidservant. I was asked to come here and offer my services to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll be paid for by a great admirer or yours who wishes to remain anon - anonymous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean? What admirer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't tell you that, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you saying that someone is paying you to be our maid and doesn't want us to know who he is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I can live in or out just as you wish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Papa, is this your idea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you playing a trick on me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never saw this girl in my life. (to Lorl) Is this a kind of joke?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at all, sir. And I was told to wait for an answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young woman, this won't do at all. My son can't possibly accept such an offer, no matter how generous, unless he knows who is behind it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I really can't tell you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, this is ridiculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is ridiculous? Wolfi has many admirers in Vienna. They love him here. People send us gifts all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you can't take her without reference. It's unheard of!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, this is none of your business. (to Lorl) Whoever sent you is going to pay, no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So now we are going to let a perfect stranger into the house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is we? Who is letting who? (to Lorl) Could you please wait outside?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, old man, you stay out of this. We spend a fortune on you, more than we can possibly afford, and all you do is criticize, morning to night. And then you think you can -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stanzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's right he should hear. I'm sick to death of it. We can't do anything right for you, can we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind. You won't have to do anything for me ever again. I'm leaving!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, I'm not staying here to be a burden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one calls you that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She does. She says I sleep all day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And so you do! The only time you come out is to eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do you expect? Who wants to walk out into a mess like this every day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, now I'm a bad housekeeper!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you are! The place is a pigsty all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mozart) Do you hear him? Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Lorl) When can you start?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right away, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! Come in. You'll start with that room there. (indicating Leopold's room) It's filthy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, sorry! I'm sorry I spoke! I'm just a provincial from Salzburg. What do I know about smart Vienna? Parties all night, every night. Dancing and drinking like idiot children!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart stands trying to blot out the noise of his father's shouting from the next room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ensemble of Ah, Tutti contenti! Saremo cosi from Act IV of Figaro resumes, coming to his aid and rising to greet the listener with its serene harmonies. Relieved, Mozart languidly picks up his cue and plays a shot on the billiard table: he is sucked back into his own world of sound.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Dinner at eight! Dinner at ten! Dinner when anyone feels like it! If anyone feels like it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The music fades. We see Lorl, dressed in a walking cloak, sitting before a desk, talking to someone confidentially.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hand comes into frame offering a plate of sugared biscuits. On its finger we see the gold signet ring belonging to Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Confused, the girl hesitates. He hands her a pile of coins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She accepts them, delighted.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're out every night, sir. Till all hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking one) Oh, thank you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do any pupils come to the house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that I've seen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then how does he pay for all this? Does he work at all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, sir, all day long. He never leaves the house until evening. He just sits there, writing and writing. He doesn't even eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? What is it he's writing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I wouldn't know that, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not. You're a good girl. You're very kind to do this. Next time you're sure they'll be out of the house, let me know, will you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, thank you, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S The final movement of Mozart's Piano Concerto in E-flat (K. 482) begins. To its lively music, the door of the house bursts open and a grand forte-piano augmented with a pedal is carried out of it by six men, who run off with it down the street. Following them immediately appear Wolfgang, Constanze and Leopold, all three dressed for an occasion. They climb into a waiting carriage which drives off after the forte-piano. As soon as it goes, Lorl appears in the doorway, peering slyly around to see that they are out of sight. Then she shuts the door and hurries off in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S An outdoor concert is being given. Mozart is actually playing the final movement of his E-flat concerto with an orchestra. Listening to him is a sizable audience, including the Emperor, flanked by Strack and Von Swieten. The crowd is in a happy and appreciative mood: it is a delightful open-air scene. We hear the gayest and most complex passage. Leopold and Constanze listen to Mozart, who plays his own work brilliantly. We stay with this scene for a little while and then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S A carriage clopping through the streets. Lorl is sitting up on the box beside the driver. Inside the vehicle, we glimpse the figure of Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear more of the concerto. Perhaps the slow interlude in the last movement of K. 482. Mozart is conducting and playing in a reflective mood. Abruptly we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S Lorl is opening the door admitting Salieri. They go in. The door shuts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S The room is considerably tidier as a result of Lorl's ministrations. Salieri stands looking about him with tremendous curiosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens a drawer in a sideboard. Inside we see one gold snuff box: it is the one we saw Mozart being presented with as a child in the Vatican.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri turns to look around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She points across the room to the workroom. Salieri crosses and goes in alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think I've found out about the money, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He kept seven snuff boxes in here. I could swear they were all gold. And now look there's only one left. And inside, sir, look - I counted them - tickets from the pawnshop. Six of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where does he work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In there, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S Salieri enters the private quarters of Amadeus. He is immensely excited. He moves slowly into the 'holy of holies' picking up objects with great reverence - a billiard ball; a discarded wig; a sock; a buckle - then objects more important to him. Standing at Mozart's desk, strewn with manuscripts, he picks up Mozart's pen and strokes the feather. He touches the inkstand. He lays a finger on the candlestick with its half-expired candle. He touches each object as if it were the memento of a beloved. He is in awe. Finally his eye falls on the sheets of music themselves. Stealthily he picks them up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pages. We see words set to music. Against each line of notes is the name of a character: Contessa, Susanna, Cherubino. Then another page - the title page - written in Mozart's hand. Le Nozze di Figaro Comedia per musica tratta dal Francese in quattro atti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The word Figaro.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri. He stares amazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: AFTERNOON - 1780'S Mozart is playing the cadenza and coda of Piano Concerto (K. 482). He completes the work with a flourish. There is loud applause. The Emperor rises and all follow suit. Mozart comes down to be greeted by him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees his wife and father standing by in the crowd. Leopold is signaling insistently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leopold comes forward eagerly and fawningly kisses the royal hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constanze curtsies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He searches his memory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the courtiers around are looking at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bravo, Mozart. Most charming. Yes, indeed. Clever man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Sire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well done, Mozart. Really quite fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Baron!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, may I ask you to do me the greatest favour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I introduce my father? He is on a short visit here and returning very soon to Salzburg. He would so much like to kiss your hand. It would make his whole stay so memorable for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah! By all means.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening. (to Leopold) We have met before, Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, Your Majesty. Twenty years ago. No, twenty-two! twenty- three! And I remember word for word what you said to me. You said - you said --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bravo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Yes, 'bravo,' of course 'bravo'! Everybody always says 'bravo' when Wolfi plays. Like the King of England. When we played for the King of England, he got up at the end and said, 'Bravo! Bravo! Bravo!' three times. Three bravo's. And the Pope four! Four bravo's from the Holy Father, and one 'bellissimo.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hush! I'm talking to His Majesty. Your Majesty, I wish to express only one thing - that you who are the Father of us all, could teach our children the gratitude they owe to fathers. It is not for nothing that the Fifth Commandment tells us: 'Honour your Father and Mother, that your days may be long upon the earth.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah-ha. Well. There it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The Director sits at his table with Salieri and Bonno.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses himself, wide-eyed with alarm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've just learned something that might be of interest to you, Herr Director.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart is writing a new opera. An Italian opera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Italian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's not all. He has chosen for his subject, Figaro. The Marriage of Figaro.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean that play?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's setting that play to music?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this Marriage of Figaro?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a French play, Kapellmeister. It has been banned by the Emperor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you absolutely sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've seen the manuscript.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S VON STRACK I know we banned this play, but frankly I can't remember why. Can you refresh my memory, Herr Director?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For the same reason, Herr Chamberlain, that it was banned in France.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, yes. And that was?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the play makes a hero out of a valet. He outwits his noble master and exposes him as a lecher. Do you see the implications? This would be, in a grander situation, as if a Chamberlain were to expose an Emperor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S The Emperor stands in the middle of the room in close conversation with Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Von Swieten, and Bonno. Salieri is not present. A door opens and a lackey announces:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all turn. Mozart approaches, rather apprehensively, and kisses Joseph's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all sit, save Mozart. The room suddenly looks like a tribunal. Joseph is in a serious mood.
direction.name: direction
