direction.raw_text: The others look at their king solemnly, all save Mozart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. All look at the Emperor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A slight pause. Then Joseph nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart falls on his knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down, gentlemen, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart, are you aware I have declared the French play of Figaro unsuitable for our theatre?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Sire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yet we hear you are making an opera from it. Is this true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who told you this, Majesty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not your place to ask questions. Is it true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yes, I admit it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you tell me why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Majesty, it is only a comedy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you think, Mozart, is scarcely the point. It is what His Majesty thinks that counts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Your Majesty -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning him to be silent) Mozart, I am a tolerant man. I do not censor things lightly. When I do, I have good reason. Figaro is a bad play. It stirs up hatred between the classes. In France it has caused nothing but bitterness. My own dear sister Antoinette writes me that she is beginning to be frightened of her own people. I do not wish to see the same fears starting here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sire, I swear to Your Majesty, there's nothing like that in the story. I have taken out everything that could give offense. I hate politics.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you are rather innocent, my friend. In these dangerous times I cannot afford to provoke our nobles or our people simply over a theatre piece.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Majesty, this is just a frolic. It's a piece about love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, love again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's new, it's entirely new. It's so new, people will go mad for it. For example, I have a scene in the second act - it starts as a duet, just a man and wife quarreling. Suddenly the wife's scheming little maid comes in unexpectedly - a very funny situation. Duet turns into trio. Then the husband's equally screaming valet comes in. Trio turns into quartet. Then a stupid old gardener - quartet becomes quintet, and so on.  On and on, sextet, septet, octet! How long do you think I can sustain that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guess! Guess, Majesty. Imagine the longest time such a thing could last, then double it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, six or seven minutes! maybe eight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty, sire! How about twenty? Twenty minutes of continuous music. No recitatives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring him) Sire, only opera can do this. In a play, if more than one person speaks at the same time, it's just noise. No one can understand a word. But with music, with music you can have twenty individuals all talking at once, and it's not noise - it's a perfect harmony. Isn't that marvelous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart, music is not the issue here. No one doubts your talent. It is your judgment of literature that's in question. Even with the politics taken out, this thing would still remain a vulgar farce. Why waste your spirit on such rubbish?  Surely you can choose more elevated themes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elevated? What does that mean? Elevated! The only thing a man should elevate is - oh, excuse me. I'm sorry. I'm stupid. But I am fed up to the teeth with elevated things! Old dead legends! How can we go on forever writing about gods and legends?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aroused) Because they do. They go on forever - at least what they represent. The eternal in us, not the ephemeral. Opera is here to ennoble us. You and me, just as much as His Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bello! Bello, Barone. Veramente.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, bello, bello, bello! Come on now, be honest. Wouldn't you all rather listen to your hairdressers than Hercules? Or Horatius? Or Orpheus? All those old bores! people so lofty they sound as if they shit marble!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Govern your tongue, sir! How dare you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive me, Majesty. I'm a vulgar man. But I assure you, my music is not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are passionate, Mozart! But you do not persuade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sire, the whole opera is finished. Do you know how much work went into it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His Majesty has been more than patient, Signore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can I persuade you if you won't let me show it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That will do, Herr Mozart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just let me tell you how it begins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I just do that, Majesty? Show you how it begins? Just that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look! There's a servant, down on his knees. Do you know why? Not from any oppression. No, he's simply measuring a space. Do you know what for? His bed. His wedding bed to see if it will fit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart sits on stage at a harpsichord rehearsing the singers taking the parts of Figaro and Susanna in the opening bars of the first act of The Marriage of Figaro. We watch Figaro measuring the space for his bed on the floor, singing and Susanna looking on, trying on the Countess' hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno are sitting with Salieri.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Mozart is already rehearsing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Incredible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Emperor has given him permission.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Si, si! Veramente.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, gentlemen, so be it. In that case I think we should help Mozart all we can and do our best to protect him against the Emperor's anger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What anger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About the ballet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ballet? What ballet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me - didn't His Majesty specifically forbid ballet in his opera?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, absolutely. Is there a ballet in Figaro?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, in the third act.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S It is a full orchestral rehearsal. Mozart is conducting from the harpsichord with his hands; he does not use a baton. The singers are all in practice clothes, not costumes. We are in the Act III and we hear the recitativo exchange just before the march begins. Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno sit watching chairs. Suddenly the march starts. Peasants and friends start to dance in and at the same moment, Orsini-Rosenberg gets up and comes down to Mozart. He is accompanied by an anxious Bonno.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He signals to the cast to break off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The company disperses, curious. The musicians look at Orsini- Rosenberg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart hands him the score from which he is conducting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rips out a page. Bonno watches in terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rips out three more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes on tearing the pages determinedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart! Herr Mozart, may I have a word with you please. Right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Certainly, Herr Director.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five minutes, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you not know that His Majesty has expressly forbidden ballet in his operas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but this is not a ballet. This is a dance at Figaro's wedding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly. A dance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But surely the Emperor didn't mean to prohibit dancing when it's part of the story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is dangerous for you to interpret His Majesty's edicts. Give me your score, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing, Herr Director?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Taking out what you should never have put in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S A servant opens the door to announce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart brushes past him straight towards Salieri, who rises to greet him. The little man is near hysterics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kisses Salieri's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart giggles with relief and gratitude.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please! Please. I've no one else to turn to. Please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfgang, what is it? Sta calmo, per favore. What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's unbelievable! The Director has actually ripped out a huge section of my music. Pages of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. They say I've got to re-write the opera, but it's perfect as it is. I can't rewrite what's perfect. Can't you talk to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why bother with Orsini-Rosenberg? He's obviously no friend of yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I could kill him! I mean really kill him. I actually threw the entire opera on the fire, he made me so angry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You burned the score?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no! My wife took it out in time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How fortunate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not fair that a man like that has power over our work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But there are those who have power over him. I think I'll take this up with the Emperor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Excellency, would you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With all my heart, Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you! Oh, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (withdrawing it; imitating the Emperor) No, no, no, Herr Mozart, please. It's not a holy relic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI I'm sure I don't need to tell you I said nothing whatever to the Emperor. I went to the theatre ready to tell Mozart that His Majesty had flown into a rage when I mentioned the ballet, when suddenly, to my astonishment, in the middle of the third act, the Emperor - who never attended rehearsals - suddenly appeared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S In the background the same recitativo before the March. The Emperor steals in surreptitiously with Von Strack, his finger to his lips. He motions everyone not to rise, and slips into a chair behind Salieri, Orsini-Rosenberg and Bonno. The three conspirators look at each other wide-eyed. The recitativo summons up the march, but instead there is silence. Mozart lays down his baton. The musicians lay down their instruments. The celebrants of Figaro's wedding come in with a few pitiful dance steps, in procession, only to come presently to a halt, lacking their music. The singers try to go on singing, but they have no cues from their conductor or from the accompaniment. Everyone on stage looks lost, though they attempt to go on with the story for a while. Consternation grows on the faces of the conspirators. Mozart glances back at the group seated in the theatre.  Finally, the Emperor speaks, in a whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart strains to hear what they are saying but cannot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do look at them. The spectacle on stage has now ground to a complete halt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orsini-Rosenberg acknowledges his defeat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orsini-Rosenberg rises and goes down to where Mozart sits anxiously with the musicians, watching his approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back deliriously at Salieri, trying to indicate his gratitude. Salieri acknowledges with a slight and subtle nod. Orsini-Rosenberg returns to his king.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The singers scatter offstage to begin the scene again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this? I don't understand. Is it modern?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Majesty, the Herr Director, he has removed a balleto that would have occurred at this place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is your regulation, Sire. No ballet in your opera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you like this, Salieri?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not a question of liking, Your Majesty. Your own law decrees it, I'm afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, look at them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no! This is nonsense. Let me hear the scene with the music.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, Sire -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oblige me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we see the scene with the music back, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, certainly. Certainly, Herr Director!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, we're going from where we stopped. The Count: Anches so. Right away, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Orsini-Rosenberg) What I hoped by that edict, Director, was simply to prevent hours of dancing like in French opera. There it is endless, as you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite so, Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mozart at the forte-piano, raising his hands. The musicians raise their bows. With a flourish the happy composer begins a reprise of the scene which had been cut out. The music of the march begins faintly; the celebrants of Figaro's wedding start to enter as the Count and the Countess sit in their chairs. In the theatre we see increasing pleasure on the Emperor's face, sullenness and defeat on the courtiers'. Then, suddenly, without interruption, on a crescendo repeat of the march, we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The theatre is brilliantly lit for the first public performance of Figaro. Everybody is there: the Emperor, Von Strack, Bonno Orsini-Rosenberg, Von Swieten, even Madame Weber and her daughters in a box. The musicians all wear imperial livery; the actors on stage are now in costume. Mozart, conducting, wears his Order of the Golden Spur. The company wheels in and around to the music of the restored march, which reaches a triumphant climax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI (to Vogler) So Figaro was produced in spite of me. And in spite of me, a wonder was revealed. One of the true wonders of art. The restored third act was bold and brilliant. The fourth was a miracle. The descending scale of strings in the final ensemble (Ah, Tutti contenti. Saremo cosi) fades in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S We see the tableau on stage with the Count kneeling to the Countess. All are singing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I saw a woman disguised in her maid's clothes hear her husband speak the first tender words he has offered her in years, only because he thinks she is someone else. I heard the music of true forgiveness filling the theatre, conferring on all who sat there a perfect absolution. God was singing through this little man to all the world - unstoppable - making my defeat more bitter with each passing bar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Salieri in his box, tears on his cheeks. He watches the ensemble and we listen to it for a long moment. Finally it fades, but continues underneath the following:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI And then suddenly - a miracle!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The ensemble reaches its climax, and fades away to the very quiet, slow chords immediately preceding the boisterous final chord. Salieri becomes aware that some of the audience are asleep and many mare are apathetic. In the near silence we see the Emperor yawn behind his hand. Those nearby look at him. Orsini-Rosenberg smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI Father, did you know what that meant? With that yawn I saw my defeat turn into a victory. And Mozart was lucky the Emperor only yawned once. Three yawns and the opera would fail the same night; two yawns, within a week at most. With one yawn the composer could still get -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1780'S Mozart is pacing up and down. Salieri is listening sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows too, giggling.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nine performances! Nine! That's all it's had - and withdrawn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know; it's outrageous. Still, if the public doesn't like one's work one has to accept the fact gracefully.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what is it they don't like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I can speak for the Emperor. You made too many demands on the royal ear. The poor man can't concentrate for more than an hour and you gave him four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you think of it yourself? Did you like it at all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's marvelous. Truly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the best opera yet written. I know it! Why didn't they come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you overestimate our dear Viennese, my friend. Do you know you didn't even give them a good bang at the end of songs so they knew when to clap?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I know. Perhaps you should give me some lessons in that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fuming) I wouldn't presume. All the same, if it wouldn't be imposing, I would like you to see my new piece. It would be a tremendous honour for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, the honour would be all mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bowing) Grazie, mio caro, Wolfgang!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grazie, a lei, Signor Antonio!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S A performance of Salieri's grand opera, Axur: King of Ormus. Deafening applause from a crowded house. We see the reception of the aria which we saw Cavalieri singing on the stage near the start of the film. Cavalieri, in a mythological Persian costume, is bowing to the rapturous throng; below her is Salieri. We see the Emperor, Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno and Von Swieten, all applauding. We hear great cries of 'Salieri! Salieri!' and 'Bravo!' and 'Brava!'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri looking at the crowd with immense pleasure. Then suddenly at:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart standing in a box and clapping wildly. Behind him, seated, are Schikaneder and the three girls we saw before in Mozart's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri staring fixedly at Mozart, then Mozart still clapping, apparently with tremendous enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) What was this? I never saw him excited before by any music but his own. Could he mean it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI (to Vogler) Would he actually tell me my music had moved him? Was I really going to hear that from his own lips? I found myself actually hurrying the tempo of the finale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Salieri conducting the last scene from Axur: King of Ormus. On stage we see a big scene of acclamation: the hero and heroine of the opera accepting the crown amidst the rejoicing of the people. The decor and costumes are mythological Persian. The music is utterly conventional and totally uninventive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart watching this in his box, with Schikaneder and the three actresses. He passes an open bottle of wine to them. He is evidently a little drunk, but keeps a poker face. The act comes to an end. Great applause in which Mozart joins in, standing and shouting 'Bravo! Bravo!' Then he leaves the box with Schikaneder and the girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S MOZART (to Schikaneder) Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schikaneder laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (mock moved) Sublime! Utterly sublime!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That kind of music should be punishable by death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S A crowd of people rings Salieri at a respectful distance. The Emperor is holding out the Civilian Medal and Chain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri bows his head. Joseph places the chain around his neck. The crowd claps. Salieri makes to kiss his hand, but Joseph restrains him, and passes on. Cavalieri, smiling adoringly, gives him a deep curtsey, and he raises her up. The crowd all flock to Salieri with cries and words of approval. All want to shake his hand. They tug and pat him. But he has eyes for only one man - he looks about him, searching for him and then finds him. Mozart stands there. Eagerly Salieri moves to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I believe that is the best opera yet written, my friends. Salieri, you are the brightest star in the musical firmament. You do honour to Vienna and to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mozart. It was good of you to come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could I not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did my work please you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could it not, Excellency?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never knew that music like that was possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You flatter me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no! One hears such sounds and what can one say, but - Salieri!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Explosive laughter as Mozart and Schikaneder enter the apartment, very pleased with themselves and accompanied by the three actresses. The front door opens, very gingerly. Mozart, still rather drunk, sticks his head into the room, anxious not to make a noise. He sees the strangers and breaks into a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the door wide to admit Schikaneder and the girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first loud chord of the Statue scene from Don Giovanni sounds. Mozart stares.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Everybody's here! We've got guests. Good. I've brought some more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll have a little party. Come in. Come in. You know Herr Schikaneder? (to a girl) This is! a very nice girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing up) Wolfi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, my love?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These gentlemen are from Salzburg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salzburg.  We were just talking about Salzburg. (to the two men, jubilantly) If you've come from my friend the Fartsbishop, you've arrived at just the right moment. Because I've got good news for him. I'm done with Vienna. It's over, finished, done with! Done with! Done with!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi! Your father is dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your father is dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The second chord sounds. On stage we see the huge figure of the Commendatore in robes and helmet, extending his arms and pointing in accusation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S The second chord sounds. On stage we see a huge nailed fist crash through the wall of a painted dining room set. The giant armoured statue of the COMMENDATORE enters pointing his finger in accusation at Don Giovanni who sits at the supper table, staring - his servant Leporello quaking with fear under the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure advances on the libertine. We see Mozart conducting, pale and deeply involved. Music fades down a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music swells. We see Salieri standing alone in the back of a box, unseen, in semi-darkness. We also see that the theatre is only half full. Music fades down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Music swells up again. We watch the scene on stage as the Commendatore addresses Giovanni. Then back to Salieri in the box. Music down again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Don Giovanni!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So rose the dreadful ghost in his next and blackest opera. There on the stage stood the figure of a dead commander calling out 'Repent! Repent!'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And I knew - only I understood - that the horrifying apparition was Leopold, raised from the dead. Wolfgang had actually summoned up his own father to accuse his son before all the world. It was terrifying and wonderful to watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 OLD SALIERI Now a madness began in me. The madness of a man splitting in half. Through my influence I saw to it Don Giovanni was played only five times in Vienna. But in secret I went to every one of those five - all alone - unable to help myself, worshipping sound I alone seemed to hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S OLD SALIERI (V.O.) And hour after hour, as I stood there, understanding even more clearly how that bitter old man was still possessing his poor son from beyond the grave, I began to see a way - a terrible way - I could finally triumph over God, my torturer. Music swells. On stage Don Giovanni is seized and gripped by the Statue's icy hand. Flames burst from obviously artificial rocks. Demons appear and drag the libertine down to Hell. The scene ends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri, staring wide-eyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S We see huge and attractive posters and billboards advertising Schikaneder's troupe. The camera concentrates on the one which reads as follows:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Impresario de luxe
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Celebrated
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An Evening of
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Music!  Mirth!  Magic!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: who personally will appear in every scene!
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: ALL SONGS AND SPEECHES WRITTEN BY EMMANUEL SCHIKANEDER

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1780'S Noise; smoke; the audience is sitting at tables for an evening of vaudeville. Mozart, Constanze and their son Karl, now about two years old, and sitting on his mother's lap, are watching a parody scene by Schikaneder's troupe. They are rowdy, bawdy and silly, incorporating motifs, situations and tunes from Mozart's operas which we have seen and heard. Before them on the table are bottles of wine and beer, plates of sausages, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On stage we see a set which parodies the dining room in Don Giovanni's palace, shown before. Schikaneder as Don Giovanni is dancing with the three actresses to the minuet from Don Giovanni (end of Act I), played by a quartet of tipsy musicians. Leporello is handing around wine on a tray. Suddenly there is a tremendous knocking from outside. The music slithers to a stop. All look at each other in panic. Leporello drops his tray with a crash. All go quiet. One more knock is heard. Then all musicians, actresses, Don Giovanni and Leporello make a dash to hide under the table which is far too small to accommodate them all. The table rocks. Schikaneder is pushed out. He is terrified. He shakes elaborately. Three more knocks are heard; louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One more knock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the pit a chromatic scale from the Overture to Don Giovanni turns into a anticipatory vamp. This grows more and more menacing until the whole flat representing the wall at the back falls down. An absurd pantomime horse gallops in. It has a ridiculous expression, and is manned by four men inside. Standing precariously on its back is a dwarf, wearing a miniature version of the armour and helmet worn by the Commendatore. He sings in a high, nasal voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tries to keep his balance as he trots in, but fails. He falls off onto the stage. He beats at the horse, trying to get back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bewildered, the horse looks about him, but cannot see his small rider who is below his level of sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The horse, amidst laughter from the audience, fails to locate him. Exasperated, the dwarf signals to someone in the wings. A tall man strides out carrying a see-saw; on his shoulders stands another man. The dwarf stands on the lowered end of the see-saw. There is a drum roll and the man above jumps down onto the raised end and the Commendatore is abruptly catapulted back onto the horse, only backwards so that he is facing away from Don Giovanni. The two men bow to the applauding audience, and retire off-stage. The Commendatore tries to extend his arms in the proper menacing attitude, and at the same time turn around to face Don Giovanni. This he finds difficult.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The horse takes a bow. The dwarf almost falls off again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The three girls rush to his aid and reach him just in time. They sing in the manner of the Tree Ladies later to be put into The Magic Flute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They grab him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives the ladies a radiant smile. The three ladies sing, as before, in close harmony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An orchestral chord. The three ladies turn to Ottavio and sing to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ottavio neighs loudly, and runs at the girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boos from the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A trapeze sails in from above. On it stands a grand soprano wearing an elaborate Turkish costume, like a parody of Cavalieri's in Il Seraglio. She comes in singing a mad coloratura scale in the manner of Martern aller Arten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He marches off stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commendatore pulls out his sword, reaches up and thrusts her through with it. The soprano collapses on the bar of the trapeze. The audience applauds. At the same moment eight dwarves march in bearing a huge cauldron of steaming water. They sing as they march to the sound of the march that was cut from Act III of Figaro. They are dressed as miniature copies of the chorus in that scene except that they are wearing cooks' hats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They set the giant pot down in the middle of the stage. The trapeze with the dead soprano is still swinging above the stage. We hear the chromatic scale from the Don Giovanni overture again, repeated and repeated, only now fast and tremolando. To this exciting vamp Schikaneder suddenly rides in on a real horse, waving a real sword. With this he cuts the string of the trapeze, and the soprano falls into the pot. A tremendous splash of water. Schikaneder rides out. More applause. All the dwarves produce long wooden cooking spoons and climb up the sides of the pot. The three girls produce labeled bottles from under their skirts. The first is SALT.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C-c-c-come in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Don Giovannnnnnnnnni!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Down! Down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm here! I'm here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Don Giovannnnnnnni!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the devil are you? What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) I've come to dinnnnnner!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dinner? How dare you? I am a nobleman. I only dine with people of my own height.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you drunk? You invited me. And my horse. Here he is. Ottavio!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa! Whoa! Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (running and singing) Be careful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (running and singing) Be careful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (running and singing) Be careful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (close harmony) Hold tight now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry) Leave me alone! Stop it! I'm a famous horseman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm a famous horse!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) He's adorable!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Adorable!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Adorable!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing together) Give me your hoof, my darling, And I'll give you my heart! Take me to your stable, And never more we'll part!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing: four male voices) I'm shy and very bashful. I don't know what to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing together) Don't hesitate a second. Just answer yes and neigh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) Stop it. What are you doing? Remember who you are! You're a horse and they are whores.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) This is ridiculous. I won't have any of it. You're turning my house into a circus!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) Shut up. Women, women, women! I'm sick to death of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing dramatically) Dash me! Bash me! Lash me! Flay me! Slay me! At last I will be freed by death!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (swinging and singing) Kill me! Kill me! Kill me! Kill me! At last I shall be freed by death. At last I shall be freed by dea -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) We're going to make a soprano stew! We're going to make a soprano stew! And when you make a soprano stew! Any stupid soprano will do! Any stew- stew-stew-stew-stew! Any stewpid soprano will do!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Behold!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (singing) Behold! She sneezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing) Behold! She hiccups. They throw them into the pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schikaneder marches in as Figaro.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking to the dwarves) How long does it take to cook a soprano?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (all together) Five hours, five minutes, five seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) I can't wait that long. I'm starving!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking; four voices) So am I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to the tune of Non piu ante) In the pot, I have got a good dinner. Not a sausage or stew, but a singer. Not a sausage or stew but a singer. Is the treat that I'll eat for my meat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh shut up. I'm sick to death of that tune.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mozart laughing delightedly with the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the dwarves climb up the rim of the pot. As they climb, they all hum together the opening of Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The soprano rises, dripping with water in the middle of the pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the dwarves beat her back down into the pot with their long wooden spoons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The table is raised in the air by Leporello sitting under it on a bale of hay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ottavio the horse gives a piercing neigh and runs down to the hay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The vamp starts again vigorously. The horse's rear-end swings around on a hinge to turn his hind-quarters straight on to the audience. The rest of him stays sideways. His tail springs up in the air to reveal a lace handkerchief modestly hiding his arsehole. Schikaneder offers him a handful of hay. The horse eats it, and out the other end comes a long Viennese sausage. The audience roars with laughter. Another handful of hay and out of the other end falls a string of sausages. Then a large pie, crust and all. Then a shower of iced cakes! Suddenly - silence. Schikaneder produces an egg from his pocket. Ottavio the horse rears up in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leporello pries open the horse's mouth. Schikaneder pops the egg into it. A breathless pause as a drum roll builds the tension, up and up and up, and then suddenly out of the horse's rear-end flies a single white dove. Wild applause. It flies into the audience. Immediately all the cast start humming the lyrical finale from Figaro: Tutti Contenti. More and more doves fly out from the wings and fill the theatre. Everybody picks up the sausages and cakes and begins to eat. The end of the sketch is unexpectedly lyrical and magical, and then, suddenly, the tempo changes and the coarse strains of Ich Mochte wohl Der Kaiser take over and the whole company is dancing, frantically. A general dance as the curtain falls. It rises immediately. The audience - including Mozart - is delighted. They applaud vigorously. Schikaneder takes a bow amongst his troupe. Among much whistling and clapping, he finally jumps off the stage and strides through the audience toward the table where Mozart sits with his family. On stage, a troupe of bag pipers immediately appears to play an old German tune. Some of the audience joins in singing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart is smiling; he has been amused. Constanze has been less amused and is looking apprehensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schikaneder sits at the table, and drinks from a bottle of wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rises in haste for his next number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He winks at Mozart and disappears toward the stage. Mozart looks after him, enchanted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles like a child.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (singing again to the horse) Give me your hoof, my darling, and I'll give you my heart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up. I'm sick of that one too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that one, too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) Oil me! Broil me! Boil me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (from inside the pot) Soil me! Foil me! Spoil me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't eat her. Sopranos give me hiccups. I want some hay!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to Schikaneder) Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to Schikaneder) Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to Schikaneder) Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to La oi daram) Give him some hay, my darling, and I'll give you my heart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leporello! We want some hay - prestissimo! Leporello - where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to horse) Behold!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to horse) Behold!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing to horse) Behold!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding on) Hey! Hey! Watch out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa! Whoa, Ottavio! Whoa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, how do you like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful! (indicating his baby son) He liked the monkey, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, well, it's all good fun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I liked the horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't he marvelous? He cost me a bundle, that horse, but he's worth it. I tell you, if you'd played Don Giovanni here it would have been a great success. I'm not joking. These people aren't fools. You could do something marvelous for them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to try them someday. I'm not sure I'd be much good at it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Course you would. You belong here, my boy, not the snobby Court. You could do anything you felt like here - the more fantastic the better! That's what people want, you know: fantasy. You do a big production, fill it with beautiful magic tricks and you'll be absolutely free to do anything you want. Of course, you'd have to put a fire in it, because I've got the best fire machine in the city and a big flood - I can do you the finest water effects you ever saw in your life. Oh, and a few trick animals. You'd have to use those.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Animals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tell you I picked up a snake in Dresden last week - twelve foot long  - folds up to six inches, just like a paper fan. It's a miracle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm serious. You write a proper part for me with a couple of catchy songs, I'll guarantee you'll have a triumph- de-luxe. Mind you, it'll have to be in German.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: German!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course! What else do you think they speak here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, I love that. I'd want it to be in German. I haven't done anything in German since Seraglio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So there you are. What do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much will you pay him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah. Well. Ah, (to Mozart) I see you've got your manager with you. Well, Madame, how about half the receipts?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Half the receipts! Stanzi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talking about now. How much will you give him now? Down payment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Down payment? Who do you think I am? The Emperor? Whoops, I have to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay where you are. You're going to like this next one. We'll speak again. Triumph-de-luxe, my boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not going to do this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? Half the house!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When? We need money now. Either he pays now, or you don't do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Stanzi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't trust this man. And I didn't like what he did with your opera. It was common.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Karl) Well, you liked it, didn't you? Monkey-flunki-punki.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Half the house! You'll never see a penny. I want it here, in my hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dirty) Stanzi-manzi, I'll put it in your hand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up! I'll not let you put anything in my hand until I see some money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dogs are barking wickedly. Michael Schlumberg comes in from his salon. Mozart stands there looking very unwell and bewildered. He is also drunk, but making a careful attempt to keep his composure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart. What a surprise. What can I do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is my pupil still anxious to learn the art of music?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, your pupil is married and living in Mannheim, young man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? Perhaps your dear wife might care to profit from my instruction?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this, Mozart? What's the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well. Since it appears nobody is eager to hire my services, could you favour me with a little money instead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If a man cannot earn, he must borrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, this is hardly the way to go about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No doubt, sir. But I am endowed with talent, and you with money. If I offer mine, you should offer yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please. I'll give it back, I promise. Please, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My answer is no, Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mozart. His voice becomes mechanical.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please. Please. Please. Please. Please. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1790'S Von Swieten and Salieri stand close together. Several scholars and students are examining scrolls and manuscripts at the other end of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The opening measures of the Piano Concerto in D Minor steal in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (keeping his voice down) This is embarrassing, you know. You introduced Mozart to some of my friends and he's begging from practically all of them. It has to stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I agree, Baron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't you think of anyone who might commission some work from him? I've done my best. I got him to arrange some Bach for my Sunday concerts. He got a fee - what I could afford. Can't you think of anyone who might do something for him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Baron, no. I'm afraid Mozart is a lost cause. He has managed to alienate practically the whole of Vienna. He is constantly drunk. He never pays his debts. I can't think of one person to whom I dare recommend him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How sad. It's tragic, isn't it? Such a talent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed. Just a moment - as a matter of fact I think I do know someone who could commission a work from him. A very appropriate person to do so. Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1790'S This is exactly the same shop which Mozart and Constanze visited with Leopold. Now Salieri's servant stands in it, waiting. We see a few other customers being served by the staff: renting masks, costumes, etc. One of the staff emerges from the back of the shop carrying a large box, which he hands to Salieri's servant. The servant leaves the shop. Through the window we see him hurrying away through the snowy street full of passers-by, carriages, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - 1790'S The D Minor Concerto continues. Salieri, alone, eagerly opens the box from the costume shop and takes out the same dark cloak and hat that Leopold wore to the masquerade, only now attached to the hat is a dark mask whose mouth is cut into a frown, not a laugh. It presents a bitter and menacing expression. He puts on the cloak, the hat and the mask and turns his back. Suddenly we see the assembled and alarming image reflected in a full-length mirror. The music swells darkly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - 1790'S As the tutti of the D Minor Concerto continues, we see Salieri, dressed in this menacing costume, dark against the snow, stalking through a street which is otherwise lively with people going to various festivities. Some of them wear frivolous carnival clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - 1790'S Mozart sits writing at a table. He appears now to be really quite sick. His face expresses pain from his stomach cramps. There is a gentle knock at the door. He rises, goes to he door and opens it. Immediately there is a SHOCK CUT: The dark, frowning mask stares at him and at us. The violent D Minor chord which opens Don Giovanni is heard. Salieri in costume stands in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The second chord sounds and fades. Mozart stares in panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri extends his hand. In it is a bag of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Almost against his will, Mozart takes the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away. Mozart closes the front door. Instantly we hear the opening of the Requiem Mass (also in D Minor). Mozart turns and looks up at the portrait of his father on the wall. The portrait stares back. Constanze opens the door from the bedroom. She sees him staring up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her with startled eyes. The music breaks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives a strange little giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sees the bag of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at her. She stares at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Mozart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have come to commission work from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mass for the dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What dead? Who is dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man who deserved a Requiem Mass and never got one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am only a messenger. Do you accept? You will be paid well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifty ducats. Another fifty when I have the Mass. Do you accept?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long will you give me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Work fast. And be sure to tell no one what you do. You will see me again soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi? Wolfi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard voices.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that? Oh! (pouncing on it) Who gave you this? How much is it? Wolfi, who gave you this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not telling you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd think I was mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1823 Old Salieri is now wildly animated, totally driven by his confession to Vogler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vogler stares at him in horror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his own hands and stares at them. The raging Dies Irae from Mozart's Requiem Mass bursts upon us.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My plan was so simple, it terrified me. First I must get the Death Mass and then achieve the death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His funeral - imagine it! The Cathedral, all Vienna sitting there. His coffin, Mozart's little coffin in the middle. And suddenly in that silence, music. A divine music bursts out over them all, a great Mass of Death: Requiem Mass for Wolfgang Mozart, composed by his devoted friend Antonio Salieri. What sublimity! What depth! What passion in the music! Salieri has been touched by God at last. And God, forced to listen. Powerless - powerless to stop it. I at the end, for once, laughing at Him. Do you understand? Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only thing that worried me was the actual killing. How does one do that? How does one kill a man? It's one thing to dream about it. It's very different when you have to do it, with your own hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Mozart sits working frantically at this demonic music. His whole expression is one of wildness and engulfing fever. He pours wine down his throat, spilling it, and grimaces as it hits his stomach. All around him are manuscripts. There is a banging at the front door. Mozart does not hear it; the music raves on. Another knocking comes, louder. Constanze appears from the bedroom and stares at her distracted husband. The knocking is repeated again, even more violently and insistently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her. The music breaks off. Silence. An enormous bang at the door startles him. Constanze moves to open it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart springs up. He is clearly terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs out of he room, into his workroom, and shuts he door. Now a little scared herself, Constanze goes to he front door and opens it cautiously. Schikaneder stands there, floridly dressed as usual. Lorl is seen peeking out from the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes her into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees he manuscript on the table, and goes to it eagerly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up a page without waiting for a reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart opens he workroom door. We see him as Schikaneder sees him: wild-eyed, extremely pale and strange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles triumphantly. Schikaneder stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart, with a bright, rather demented smile presents his head to Schikaneder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He giggles. Schikaneder suddenly grabs his lapels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schikaneder suddenly takes Mozart by the arms, and speaks to him with intense appeal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi. Wolfi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Don't answer it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell him I'm not here. Tell him I'm working on it. Come back later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I interrupting something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (peering into he room) Where's our friend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not in. But he's working on it. He said to tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope so. I need it immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he happy with it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the devil is this? Requiem Mass? Does he think I'm in the funeral business?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave that alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put it down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put it down, I said! It's nothing for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! I'm sorry! I'm sorry! What have you got for me? Is it finished?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? The vaudeville, what'd you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I see it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because there's nothing to see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I asked you if we could start rehearsal next week and you said yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So let me see it. Where is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here. It's all right here, in my noodle. The rest is just scribbling. Scribbling and bibbling. Bibbling and scribbling. Would you like a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, you little clown, do you know how many people I've hired for you? Do you know how many people are waiting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave him alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm paying these people. Do you realize that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's doing his best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm paying people just to wait for you. It's ridiculous!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what's ridiculous? Your libretto, that's what's ridiculous. Only an idiot would ask Wolfi to work on that stuff!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes? And what's so intelligent about writing a Requiem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Money! Money!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're mad! She's mad, Wolfi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, and who are you? He's worked for Kings. For the Emperor. (shouting) Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Wolfi. Write it. Please. Just write it down. On paper. It's no good to anyone in your head. And fuck the Death Mass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1790'S A frightened and tearful Lorl sits before Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Overture to The Magic Flute begins grandly. To the music of the slow introduction, we see:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now calm yourself. Calm. What's the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm leaving. I'm not working there anymore. I'm scared!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? What has happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't know what it's like. Herr Mozart frightens me. He drinks all day, then takes all that medicine and it makes him worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What medicine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. He has pains.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, in his stomach. They bend him right over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he working?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm frightened, sir. Really! When he speaks, he doesn't make any sense. You know he said he saw - he said he saw his father. And his father's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he working?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose so. He sits there all he time, doing some silly opera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) Opera? Opera!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't ask me to go back again. I'm frightened! I'm very, very frightened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (insistently) Are you sure it's an opera?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S The room, lit by a few candles, appears dirty. The camera shows us again Leopold's portrait on the wall, looking down upon a scene of disorder. Papers litter the table; dirty dishes are piled in the fireplace; on the forte-piano lies Mozart's Masonic apron, woven with symbols. To the more lyrical passage of the introduction, we see Mozart take up a candle and enter:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S We watch him stand beside Constanze, who lies asleep. Mozart now looks very ill; his wife appears worn out. Tenderly he touches her hair. Then he moves to the cot where his son Karl lies asleep and kneels, pulls up the child's little blanket and for a moment lays his own head down beside the boy's. Constanze opens her eyes and stares at him. Mozart rises and returns to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S The Introduction ends and suddenly the brilliant fast fugue begins. Instantly Mozart starts to dance to it, all alone: gleefully, like a child. He looks up at his father's portrait, and makes a silly, rude gesture at it. He is, briefly, an irresponsible and happy boy again. Then suddenly there is a gentle knocking at the door. The music fades down. Warily, Mozart crosses and opens he door. The familiar dark chords from Don Giovanni cut across the happy music. It ends. Before him stands the masked stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and looks. Constanze has come into the living room. Nervously, Mozart indicates her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri contemplates them both.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and goes down the stairs. Mozart shuts the door; he closes his eyes in fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He will not look at her or reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly she starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her tears flow. Mozart looks at her helplessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits down tearfully, staring at him. We hear the Rex Tremendai Majestatis from the Requiem and see on the wall the portrait of Leopold Mozart looking down. The camera pans slowly downward from it back to the table. Mozart is writing the music. He looks up and sees that Constanze is fast asleep in her chair. Mozart gets up quietly. He puts on his hat and cloak, takes a bottle of wine and tiptoes from the house. Without stopping, the music changes from the heavy Requiem to the light-hearted patter of the Papa-Papa duet from The Magic Flute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have it yet. It's not finished. I'm sorry, but I need more time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you neglecting my request?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no! I promise you, I'll give you a wonderful piece - the best I ever can!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is my wife, Stanzi. I've been sick, but I'm all right now. Aren't I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes, sir. He's all right. And he's working on it very hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me two more weeks. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The sooner you finish, the better your reward. Work!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi, I think you really are going mad. You work like a slave for that idiot actor who won't give you a penny and here. This is not a ghost! This is a real man who puts down real money. Why on earth don't you finish it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me one reason I can understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't write it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's killing me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, this is really awful. You're drunk, aren't you? Be honest - tell me - you've been drinking. And I'm so stupid I stay here and listen to you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not fair! I worry about you all the time. I try to help you all I can and you just drink and talk nonsense and - and frighten me! It's not fair!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go back to bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please! Let me sit here. Let me stay here with you. I promise I won't say all word. I'll just be here, so you know no one's going to hurt you. Please, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S This little wooden structure stands in a courtyard in the tenement by the Weiden. Inside, we see a table, chairs, a forte-piano, bottles and a chaos of papers. Strewn about in the chairs are the three actresses, giggling. Schikaneder and Mozart, both drunk, are singing the duet of the two bird- people. The actor sings Papageno and the composer, in a soprano voice, sings Papagena at the keyboard. Absurdly, they end up rubbing noses and fall on each other's necks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Mozart, drunk and happy, staggers back through the snow. There are a few people about. He goes into his apartment building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1790'S He comes through he door and stares across the living room at an open bedroom door. Puzzled, he crosses. The bedroom is also empty. We see Constanze's empty bed; Karl's empty bed; empty closets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks about him, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stanzi? Stanzi-marini-bini?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - 1790'S Frau Weber sits grimly talking. Mozart sits also, completely exhausted and passive under the rain of her constant speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with a scream Madame Weber's voice turns into the shrill packing coloratura of the second act aria of the Queen of the Night, in The Magic Flute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She's not coming back, you know. She's gone for good. I did it and I'm proud of it. 'Leave,' I said. 'Right away! Take he child and go, just go. Here's the money! Go to the Spa and get your health back - that's if you can.' I was shocked. Shocked to my foundation. Is that my girl? Can that be my Stanzi? The happy little moppet I brought up, that poor trembling thing? Oh, you monster! No one exists but you, do they? You and your music! Do you know how often she's sat in that very chair, weeping her eyes out of her head because of you? I warned her. 'Choose a man, not a baby,' I said. But would she listen? Who listens? 'He's just a silly boy,' she says. Silly, my arse. Selfish - that's all you are. Selfish! Selfish, selfish, selfish, selfish, selfish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S On stage we see the QUEEN OF THE NIGHT fantastically costumed, furiously urging her daughter to kill Sarastro. As she sings, we see the interior of the theatre, now re-arranged from when we last visited it to watch the Cabaret. An audience of ordinary German citizens stands in the pit area, or sits: they are rapt and excited. The theatre also possesses boxes; some of these show closed curtains - their inhabitants presumably engaged in private intimacies. In one of them sits Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thunder and lightning. She disappears amidst tremendous applause from the audience.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (singing furiously) A hellish wrath within my heart is seething! Death and destruction Flame around my throne! If not by thee Sarastro's light be extinguished. Then be thou mine own daughter never more! Rejected be forever! So sundered be forever All the bonds of kin and blood! Hear! Hear! Hear God of Vengeance! Hear thy Mother's vow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S On the poster for The Magic Flute, the name Emmanuel Schikaneder should appear very, very large and the name of Mozart quite small: I. & R. priv. Weiden Theatre The Actors of the Imperial and Royal Privileged Theatre of the Weiden Have the honour to perform
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music is by Herr Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Herr Mozart out of respect for a gracious and honourable Public, and from friendship for the author of this piece, will today direct the orchestra in person. The book of the opera, furnished with two copperplates, of which is engraved Herr Schikaneder in the costume he wears for the role of Papageno, may be had at the box office for 30 kr. Prices of admission are as usual To begin at 7 o'clock
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Grand Opera in Two Acts By Emmanuel Schikaneder (The Cast List)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We CUT TO the scene immediately before Papageno's song, Ein Madchen oder Weibchen. Papageno, played by Schikaneder, dressed in his costume of feathers, is trying to get through a mysterious door. A voice calls from within.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papageno recoils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papageno recoils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He weeps extravagantly. In the pit, Mozart indicates to the first violinist to take over as conductor. He slips from his place and goes stealthily backstage. We follow him. Over the scene we hear Papageno being addressed by the First Priest in stern tones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter. An enormous goblet of wine appears out of the earth. We follow Mozart into the wings. Actors and actresses stand around in fantastic costumes. We see a flying chariot and parts of a huge snake lying about. Also the scenery door of a temple with the word 'Wisdom' inscribed on the pediment. Mozart walks to where there stands a keyboard glockenspiel with several manuals, and a musician waiting to play it. Silently Mozart indicates that he wishes to play the instrument himself. On stage Schikaneder is being addressed haughtily by the First Priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter from the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at the audience and winks at them. They laugh. Now Papageno's aria (Ein Madchen oder Weibchen) begins. It is interpolated, as he pretends to play his magic bells, with the glockenspiel actually being played off-stage by Mozart. Schikaneder looks into the pit and does not see Mozart conducting. He looks into the wings and realizes the situation with amusement. He sings joyfully and the audience watches entranced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At certain moments we see the stage from Salieri's point of view: Schikaneder singing, then pretending to play; and then we see Mozart playing the glockenspiel with great flourishes in the wings. Then, suddenly, the actor mimes playing, and no sound comes. He mimes again, but still nothing comes. He looks offstage in anxiety; there is evidently some commotion. People are looking down on the floor. The song comes to a near-halt. Schikaneder stares. Then the comedian signals to the deputy conductor to pick up the song and finish it. At this moment Salieri gets up and hastily leaves his box.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: STAGE, AUDITORIUM AND WINGS OF SCHIKANEDER'S THEATRE

dialogue.raw_text: Go back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merciful Gods! If only I knew by which door I came in. (to audience) Which was it? Was it this one? Come on, tell me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, I can't go forward and I can't go back. Oh, this is awful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on stage) Man, thou hast deserved to wander forever in the darkest chasms of the earth. The gentle Gods have remitted thy punishment, but yet thou shalt never feel the Divine Content of the consecrated ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh well, I'm not alone in that. Just give me a decent glass of wine - that's divine content enough for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man, hast thou no other desire on earth, but just to eat and drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Schikaneder) Well!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, actually I do have a rather weird feeling in my heart. Perhaps it's just indigestion. But you know, I really would like - I really do want - something even nicer than food and drink. Now what on earth could that be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A sweetheart or a pretty little wife is Papageno's wish. A willing, billing, lovey dovey Would be My most tasty little dish. Be my most tasty little dish! Be my most tasty little dish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then that would be eating and drinking I'd live like a Prince without thinking. The wisdom of old would be mine - A woman's much better than wine! Then that would be eating and drinking! The wisdom of old would be mine - A woman's much better than wine. She's much better than wine! She's much better than wine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (encore, lightly, as before) A sweetheart or a pretty little wife is Papageno's wish. A willing, billing, lovey dovey Would be My most tasty little dish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need to net one birdie only And I will stop feeling so lonely. But if she won't fly to my aid, Then into a ghost I must fade. I need to net one birdie only But if she won't fly to my aid, Then into a ghost I must fade.  To a ghost I must fade! To a ghost I must fade!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (encore) A sweetheart or a pretty little wife is Papageno's wish. A willing, billing, lovey dovey Would be My most tasty little dish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At present the girls only peck me. Their cruelty surely will wreck me. But one little beak in my own, And I'll up to heaven be flown! At present the girls only peck me. But one little beak in my own, And I'll up to heaven be flown. Up to heaven be flown! Up to heaven be flown!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S We see the actress playing Papagena, wearing an old tattered cloak and about to tie a little painted cloth representing a hideous old woman over her face. She is looking worriedly down at Mozart, who is lying unconscious on the floor. A few people around him are trying to revive him. One has put a wet handkerchief around his temples. Another is holding a small bottle of smelling salts. There are voices saying, 'Doctor! Take him to a dressing room. Someone call a carriage. Take him home.' Etc. Papagena is urged to go on stage by a distracted stage manager. Suddenly we hear the voice of Salieri.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The actors step back respectfully. He stoops and picks up the frail composer in his arms. Mozart is quite limp and Salieri has to fling his arms around his own neck. All this is watched nervously by Schikaneder on stage whilst performing his scene with Papagena as an ugly old woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Audience laughter. The actress raises the little painted cloth with the ugly old face on it to show her own pretty young one to the audience. More laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take care of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a carriage. Excuse me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here I am, my angel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (appalled) What? Who the devil are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've taken pity on you, my angel. I heard your wish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Well, thank you! How wonderful. Some people get all the luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you've got to promise me faithfully you'll remain true to me forever. Then you'll see how tenderly your little birdie will love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervous) I can't wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, promise then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean - now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course now. Right away, before I get any older.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know! I mean you're a delicious, delightful, delectable little bird, but don't you think you might be just a little tough?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amorously) Oh, I'm tender enough for you, my boy. I'm tender enough for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S A waiting sedan chair. Mozart has recovered consciousness, but looks exceedingly ill. Salieri has set him down in the winter's night. Snow is falling.
direction.name: direction
