direction.raw_text: He starts to collapse again. Salieri helps him into the sedan. The door is shut. The chair sets off and Salieri strides beside it, through the mean street. A lantern with a candle swings from the chair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened? Is it over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm taking you home. You're not well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no. I have to get back. I have -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S The door opens. Salieri enters carrying the lantern from the sedan chair. He is followed by Mozart, carried in the arms of one of the porters. The room is now really in complete disarray. The table is piled high with music: the pages of the Requiem lie amongst many empty wine bottles. The porter carries Mozart into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S This room is miserably neglected. The bed is unmade, clothes lie about on the floor. A sock has been stuck into the broken pane of one window. The porter lays Mozart down on the bed as Salieri lights candles from the lantern to reveal plates of half-eaten food and other signs left by a man whose wife has departed. It is obviously very cold. Another very small bed nearby belongs to the child, Karl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The porter leaves the room. Mozart stirs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens his eyes and sees Salieri staring down at him. He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He helps him to sit up and takes off his coat and his shoes and puts a coverlet around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He struggles to loosen his cravat. Salieri does it for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a violent knocking at the front door. Mozart starts and looks around wildly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The knocking increases in loudness, terrifying Mozart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri moves to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (handing the porter the lantern) Thank you. Go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely singing) Papa! Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is your wife?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not here! She's not well, either. She went to the Spa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean she's not coming back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're so good to me. Truly. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean to come to my opera. You are the only colleague who did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would never miss anything that you had written. You must know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is only a vaudeville.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no. It is a sublime piece. The grandest operone. I tell you, you are the greatest composer known to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you mean that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have bad fancies. I don't sleep well anymore. Then I drink too much, and think stupid things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you ill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The doctor thinks I am. But -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm too young to be so sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall I answer it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! No, it's him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man. He's here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell him to go away. Tell him I'm still working on it. Don't let him in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! Ask him if he'd give me some money now. Tell him if he would, that would help me finish it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows. He knows!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Salieri goes to the front door and opens it to reveal Schikaneder, who has obviously come straight from the theatre. He still wears his bird make-up and under his street cloak, his feathered costume is clearly seen. He has with him the three actresses, also looking anxious and also in make-up as the three attendants in The Magic Flute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schikaneder produces a bag of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They bob and curtsey. Schikaneder stares at Salieri, uneasily, vaguely suspicious. Salieri smiles back at him and shuts the door. He stays for a moment, thinking. He contemplates the money.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Herr Salieri.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I am looking after him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we come in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, he's sleeping now. Better not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he's all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes. He's just exhausted. He became dizzy, that's all. We should let him rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, tell him we were here, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And say everything went wonderfully. A triumph-de-luxe - say that! Tell him the audience shouted his name a hundred times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bene.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll call tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. (to the actresses) And congratulations to all of you. It was superb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you! Thank you, Excellency!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, by the way, give him this. This is his share. That should cheer him up, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, indeed. Goodnight to you all now. It was perfection - truly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delighted) Goodnight, Your Excellency. Goodnight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Mozart is sitting up in bed, staring at the door. It opens. Salieri returns. He holds in his hand the bag of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri pours the coins out of the bag onto the coverlet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart looks at the coins astonished.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said to give you this. And if you finish the work by tomorrow night, he will pay you another hundred ducats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another? But that's too soon! Tomorrow night? It's impossible! Did he say a hundred?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Can I - could I help you, in any way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you? Actually, you could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My dear friend, it would be my greatest pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you'd have to swear not to tell a soul. I'm not allowed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, it's all here in my head. It's just ready to be set down. But when I'm dizzy like this my eyes won't focus. I can't write.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then, let us try together. I'd regard it as such an honour. Tell me, what is this work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mass. A Mass for the Dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Trivial dance music is playing. Constanze is doing a waltz with a young OFFICER in military uniform. At the moment we see her, she stops abruptly, as if in panic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go back to Vienna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel wrong. I feel wrong being here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laying a hand on her arm) What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Mozart is sitting up in bed, propped against pillows. The coins lie on the coverlet; many candles burn in the necks of bottles. Salieri, without coat or wig, is seated at an improvised worktable. On it are blank sheets of music paper, quills, and ink. Also the score of the Requiem Mass as so far composed. Mozart is bright-eyed with a kind of fever. Salieri is also possessed with an obviously feverish desire to put down the notes as quickly as Mozart can dictate them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes his pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri writes the key signature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri writes this, and continues now to write as swiftly and urgently as he can, at Mozart's dictation. He is obviously highly expert at doing this and hardly hesitates. His speed, however, can never be too fast for Mozart's impatient mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri sings back the first six measures of the bass line. After the first two measures a chorus of basses fades in on the soundtrack and engulfs his voice. They stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice is lost on the last words, as tenors engulf it and take over the soundtrack, singing their whole line from the beginning, right to the end of the sixth measure where the basses stopped, but he goes on mouthing the sounds with them. Salieri writes feverishly. We see his pen jotting down the notes as quickly as possible: the ink flicks onto the page. The music stops again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart glares at him, irritated. His hands move impatiently. Salieri scribbles frantically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He again hums the bass vocal line from the beginning, conducting. On the soundtrack, we hear the second bassoon and bass trombone play it with him and the first bassoon and tenor trombone come in on top, playing the tenor vocal line. We also hear the trumpets and timpani. The sound is bare and grim. It stops at the end of the sixth measure. Salieri stops writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sings the urgent first measure of the ostinato.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sings the second measure of the ostinato.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri sings the first two measures of the string ostinato.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Salieri writes, Mozart sings the ostinato from the beginning, but the unaccompanied strings overwhelm his voice on the soundtrack, playing the first six bars of their agitated accompaniment. They stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is now sitting bolt upright, hushed and inspired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He writes feverishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sings the violin figure under the Voca Me (Bars 7,8,9).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sings the ostinato phrase twice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The entire Confutatis bursts over the room, as Mozart snatches the manuscript pages from Salieri and reads from it, singing. Salieri sits looking on in wondering astonishment. The music continues right through the following scenes, to the end of the movement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where did I stop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (consulting the manuscript) The end of the Recordare - Statuens in parte dextra.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So now the Confutatis. Confutatis Maledictis. When the wicked are confounded. Flammis acribus addictis. How would you translate that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Consigned to flames of woe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you believe in it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A fire which never dies. Burning one forever?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Strange!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come. Let's begin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Confutatis Maledictis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We ended in F Major?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So now - A minor. Suddenly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Common time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Start with the voices. Basses first. Second beat of the first measure - A. (singing the note) Con-fu-ta-tis. (speaking) Second measure, second beat. (singing) Ma-le-dic-tis. (speaking) G-sharp, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Third measure, second beat starting on E. (singing) Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis. (speaking) And fourth measure, fourth beat - D. (singing) Ma-le-dic-tis, flam-mis a-cri-bus ad- dic-tis. (speaking) Do you have that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sing it back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Now the tenors. Fourth beat of the first measure - C. (singing) Con-fu-ta-tis. (speaking) Second measure, fourth beat on D. (singing) Ma-le-dic-tis. (speaking) All right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fourth measure, second beat - F. (singing) Flam-mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis, flam- mis a-cri-bus ad-dic-tis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now the orchestra. Second bassoon and bass trombone with the basses. Identical notes and rhythm. (He hurriedly hums the opening notes of the bass vocal line) The first bassoon and tenor trombone -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (labouring to keep up) Please! Just one moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It couldn't be simpler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finishing) First bassoon and tenor trombone - what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With the tenors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Also identical?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly. The instruments to go with the voices. Trumpets and timpani, tonic and dominant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no. Now for the Fire. (he smiles) Strings in unison - ostinato on all - like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) Second measure on B.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) Do you have me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) Good, good - yes! Put it down. And the next measures exactly the same, rising and rising - C to D to E, up to the dominant chord. Do you see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's wonderful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, yes - go on. The Voca Me. Suddenly sotto voce. Write that down: sotto voce, pianissimo. Voca me cum benedictis. Call me among the blessed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Major. Sopranos and altos in thirds. Altos on C. Sopranos above. (singing the alto part) Vo-ca, vo-ca me, vo-ca me cum be-ne- dic-tis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sopranos up to F on the second 'Voca'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, and on 'dictis'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And underneath, just violins - arpeggio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) The descending scale in eighth notes, and then back suddenly to the fire again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking) And that's it. Do you have it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You go fast!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (urgently) Do you have it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then let me hear it. All of it. The whole thing from the beginning - now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WINTER NIGHT - 1790'S A carriage is driving fast through the night. Snow lies on the countryside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE CARRIAGE  NIGHT - 1790'S The carriage is filled with passengers. Among them Constanze and Karl, her young son. They are sleepless and sway to the motion of the vehicle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Mozart lying in bed exhausted, but still dictating urgently. We do not hear what he is saying to Salieri, who still sits writing assiduously. Mozart is looking very sick: sweat is pouring from his forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WINTER NIGHT - 1790'S The carriage, moving through the night, to the sound of the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S Mozart still dictating; Salieri still writing without stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAWN - 1790'S. The carriage has arrived. Constanze and her son alight with other passengers. Postillions attend to the horses. She takes her boy's hand. It is a cold wintry dawn. The music stutters to a close. End of the Confutatis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - 1790'S MOZART Do you want to rest a bit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart closes his eyes. Salieri stares at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no. I'm not tired at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll stop for just a moment. Then we'll do the Lacrimosa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can keep going, I assure you. Shall we try?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you stay with me while I sleep a little?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not leaving you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am so ashamed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was foolish. I thought you did not care for my work - or me. Forgive me. Forgive me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WINTRY DAWN - 1790'S Constanze and Karl approach along the cobbled street, hand in hand toward their house. Snow lies in the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAWN - 1790'S Mozart lies asleep in the bed, holding the last pages of the manuscript. Salieri lies across from him on Karl's small bed in his shirt sleeves and waistcoat. The child's bed is obviously too small for him and he is forced in to a cramped position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAWN - 1790'S Constanze and Karl arrive at the door. They enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAWN - 1790'S It is as disordered as before, save that the table, previously littered with pages, is now completely bare. Constanze looks at it with surprise and enters the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAWN - 1790'S Mozart is asleep in the bed. Salieri is dozing on the nearby child's bed. The room is full of the trailing smoke from guttering and guttered candles. Startled by Constanze's entrance and her young son, Salieri scrambles up. As he does so, he attempts to button his waistcoat, but does it ineptly, so that the vestment becomes bunched up, making him look absurd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She notices a movement from the bed. Mozart wakes. He sees Constanze and smiles with real joy. Forgetting Salieri, she goes to her husband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She throws herself on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hugs her husband desperately. He stares at her with obvious relief, not able to speak. Suddenly she sees the manuscript in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at it and recognizes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes it from his weak hand. At the same moment Salieri reaches out his hand to take it and add it to the pile on the table. She stares at him, trying to understand - suspicious and frightened and at the same time unable to make a sound. Mozart makes a convulsive gesture to reclaim the pages. The coins brought by Salieri fall on the floor.  Karl runs after them, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She extends her hand for the Requiem, as she stands up. Salieri hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With extreme reluctance - it costs him agony to do it - Salieri hands over the score of the Requiem to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She marches with the manuscript over to a large chest in the room, opens it, throws the manuscript inside, shuts the lid, locks it and pockets the key. Involuntarily Salieri stretches out his arms for the lost manuscript.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and faces him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at her, stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other in mutual hatred. She turns to the bed. Mozart appears to have gone to sleep again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves to the bed. The child is playing with the coins on the floor. Faintly we hear the start of the Lacrimosa from the Requiem. Salieri watches as she touches her husband's hand. As the music grows, we realize that Mozart is dead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your husband is ill, ma'am. He took sick. I brought him home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was at hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, thank you very much. You can go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He needs me, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he doesn't. And I don't want you here. Just go, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He asked me to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm asking you -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi, I'm back. I'm still very angry with you, but I missed you so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll never leave you again. If you'll just try a little harder to be nice to me. And I'll try to do better, too. We must. We must! This was just silly and stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no, not this. Not this, Wolfi! You're not to work on this ever again! I've decided.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Salieri) This is not his handwriting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I was assisting him. He asked me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not going to work on this anymore. It is making him ill. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hard) Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But - but - but -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I regret we have no servants to show you out, Herr Salieri. Respect my wish and go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame, I will respect his. He asked me to stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wolfi? (louder) Wolfi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Constanze staring wide-eyed in dawning apprehension.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri also comprehending hat he has been cheated. The music rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The child on the floor, playing with the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A RAINY DAY - 1790'S The Lacrimosa continues through all of the following: a small group of people emerges from the side door into the raw, wet day, accompanying a cheap wooden coffin. The coffin is borne by a gravedigger and Schikaneder in mourning clothes. They load it onto a cart, drawn by a poor black horse. All the rest are in black, also: Salieri, Von Swieten, Constanze and her son, Karl, Madame Weber and her youngest daughter Sophie, and even Lorl, the maid. It is drizzling. The cart sets off. The group follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: RAINY DAY - 1790'S The group has already passed beyond the city limits following the miserable cart. The Lacrimosa accompanies them with its measured thread. The drizzle of rain has now become heavy. One by one, the group breaks up and shelters under the trees. The cart moves on toward the cemetery, alone, followed by nobody, growing more and more distant. They watch it go. Salieri and Von Swieten shake hands mournfully, the water soaking their black tall hats. Schikaneder is in tears. Constanze is near collapse. Salieri moves to assist her, but she turns away from him, seeking the arm of Cavalieri. Madame Weber takes Karl's hand. The music builds to its climax on Dona Eis Pacem! We CUT back to:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: OUTSIDE THE CITY WALLS OF VIENNA

direction.raw_text: MORNING - 1823 Morning light fills the room. Old Salieri sits weeping convulsively, as the music stops. Tears stream down his face. Vogler watches him, amazed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery by confessing to murder? You didn't kill him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you didn't!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I poisoned his life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But not his body.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What difference does that make?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My son, why should you want all Vienna to believe you a murderer? Is that your penance? Is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Father. From now on no one will be able to speak of Mozart without thinking of me. Whenever they say Mozart with love, they'll have to say Salieri with loathing. And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my son, my poor son!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart, not I. Took him, snatched him away, without pity. He destroyed His beloved rather than let a mediocrity like me get the smallest share in his glory. He doesn't care. Understand that. God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MARX - LATE AFTERNOON - 1790'S The rain has eased off. A LOCAL PRIEST with two boy acolytes is standing beside an open communal grave. Mozart's body is lifted out of the cheap pine box in a sack. We see that the grave contains twenty other such sacks. The gravedigger throws the one containing Mozart amongst the others. An assistant pours quicklime over the whole pile of them. The acolytes swing their censers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Lord giveth. The Lord taketh away. Blessed be the name of the Lord.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MORNING - 1823 OLD SALIERI Why did He do it? Why didn't He kill me? I had no value. What was the use, keeping me alive for thirty-two years of torture? Thirty-two years of honours and awards. He tears off the Civilian Medal and Chain with which the Emperor invested him and has been wearing the whole time and throws it across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens. An attendant comes in, cheerful and hearty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Salieri ignores him and stares only at the priest, who stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He signs to the attendant, who wheels him in his chair out of the room. The priest stares after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Being bowed to and saluted, called 'distinguished - distinguished Salieri' - by men incapable of distinguishing! Thirty-two years of meaningless fame to end up alone in my room, watching myself become extinct. My music growing fainter, all the time fainter, until no one plays it at all. And his growing louder, filling the world with wonder. And everyone who loves my sacred art crying, Mozart! Bless you, Mozart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Professor! Time for the water closet. And then we've got your favourite breakfast for you - sugar-rolls. (to Vogler) He loves those. Fresh sugar-rolls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Father. I'll speak for you. I speak for all mediocrities in the world. I am their champion. I am their patron saint. On their behalf I deny Him, your God of no mercy. Your God who tortures men with longings they can never fulfill. He may forgive me: I shall never forgive Him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The corridor is filled with patients in white linen smocks, all taking their morning exercise walk in the care of nurses and nuns. They form a long, wretched, strange procession - some of them are clearly very disturbed. As Old Salieri is pushed through them in his wheelchair, he lifts his hands to them in benediction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, he turns full-face to the camera and blesses us the audience, making the Sign of the Cross. Underneath we hear, stealing in and growing louder, the tremendous Masonic Funeral Music of Mozart. On the last four chords, we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mediocrities everywhere, now and to come: I absolve you all! Amen! Amen! Amen!
dialogue.name: dialogue
